prompt: Please create rules for a new card game. It should be a game that utilizes a standard deck of 52 cards (no jokers). The game should utilize the whole deck. This should be a two-player game. Make the game have some association with baseball. There should be nine innings or each player should be up nine times.
messages:
[{'content': 'Please create rules for a new card game. It should be a game that utilizes a standard deck of 52 cards (no jokers). The game should utilize the whole deck. This should be a two-player game. Make the game have some association with baseball. There should be nine innings or each player should be up nine times.
', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': "Shuffle the cards and spread them randomly on a table. If you wish, arrange them in a diamond shape and place some cards above the diamond to represent the outfield. All cards should be placed face-down. 

This is a two-player game. One player is the Away team and the other one is the Home team. The Away team goes first and picks a card. This pick determines the runs scored by the Away team for that inning (starting with 1st inning). If a number card (2-8) is drawn, the player scores the number of runs that matches the number on the card. If an Ace is drawn that counts as zero because the player faced a great pitcher which is often referred to in baseball as an Ace. Then that player's turn is over and the next player goes. All other cards (Jacks, Queens, and Kings) are worth 1 run. 

Also, look at the suit. If the suit is a diamond add a run to the inning since diamond is a baseball term. It is a term for the area of the field that is enclosed by the home plate and the bases.

Next, the Home team picks a card in the bottom of the first. Determine how many runs the Home team scored. Keep score for both teams for all innings. Go 9 innings and if it is tied after nine innings well then it ends in a tie lol. If not, the team that scored the most runs WINS.", 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: Write a 12 page children‚Äôs story about adopting a baby kitten from a shelter. Don‚Äôt include more than 3 sentences per page.
messages:
[{'content': 'Write a 12 page children‚Äôs story about adopting a baby kitten from a shelter. Don‚Äôt include more than 3 sentences per page.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': 'Page 1: Tommy was so excited that Saturday had finally arrived. Today was the day his parents were taking him to the animal shelter to adopt a new furry friend!

Page 2: Tommy didn‚Äôt know what type of pet he would be bringing home. Maybe it would be a dog he could play fetch with! Or maybe a cat that would hang out with him while he read books.

Page 3: On the drive to the shelter, he thought about what names he might choose. Mabel is too common, and so is Spike, he thought to himself.

Page 4: Upon arriving at the shelter, a nice lady met them at the door, introduced herself as Joyce, and asked if we wanted to take a look around. ‚ÄúThere are so many pets available for you to adopt!‚Äù she said.

Page 5: Joyce walked them through the shelter and showed them the different animals that needed a good home. There were so many dogs and cats in cages that Tommy didn‚Äôt know how he could possibly choose one.

Page 6: Then, Tommy spotted a baby kitten in one of the smaller cages. This kitten had all-white fur with blue eyes and stared directly into his eyes. He felt an instant connection.

Page 7: ‚ÄúThis is the one!‚Äù Tommy exclaimed as he pointed at the white kitten. His parents beamed back proudly and turned to face Joyce. ‚ÄúI believe we have found our new pet,‚Äù Tommy‚Äôs mother told her.

Page 8: ‚ÄúGreat! I will get the adoption paperwork ready for you. Would you like to hold your new kitten while you wait?‚Äù Joyce asked Tommy. ‚ÄúOf course I would!‚Äù he said excitedly.

Page 9: Tommy sat down on the floor as Joyce put the kitten into his lap. The kitten immediately started purring, and Tommy couldn‚Äôt help but to have the biggest grin on his face.

Page 10: ‚ÄúI think I‚Äôll name you Cloud. Because clouds are white and fluffy, just like you!‚Äù Tommy said to the kitten.

Page 11: Joyce came back into the room. ‚ÄúThe paperwork is all done! You are all set to take your new kitten home with you,‚Äù she told Tommy. ‚ÄúDid you pick out a name yet?‚Äù

Page 12: ‚ÄúHer name is Cloud. She will be my best friend forever,‚Äù Tommy said with pride.', 'role': 'assistant'}]

Reference Barbie as the fashion icon of the doll industry including the ways her designers have adapted to these changes as well. It should be 3 sentences minimum but no more than 5. It should have a professional yet approachable tone.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': 'Flip a few pages in a magazine or watch an ad or two on your favorite video-streaming platform and you\'re sure to notice that the "face" of the fashion world sure has changed throughout the years. The fashion industry was once an illusive club catering to a very specific type of individual, but it has made leaps and bounds over the last decades to become an all-inclusive profession where people of all shapes, sizes, ethnicities and intellectual statuses can succeed. Starting with the addition of plus-sized models, followed by alternative (alt) models, nonwhite models, and disabled models, there has been a steady transformation within this sector. The ability to connect with someone who looks like, sounds like or lives like you guarantees all young girls will have the confidence to be the best version of themself without the pressure to conform to the beauty standards of the world. Support from the most popular fashion doll, Barbie, definitely reinforces this outstanding merit.', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt:
Turn these paragraphs into a casual email meant for a friend named Bowen curious about the Legend of Faust.

Faust or Faustus is a scholar who sells his soul to the Devil. Although fictional in literature, the legend is based on an astrologer and alchemist who lived in the area of northern Germany in the fifteenth century.

Trained in theology, he turns to magic and makes a perilous deal with the Devil in which he commits his soul to eternal damnation in return for power and knowledge in this life. But he is only human, and arrogant and reckless. Can Faust ‚Äî or anyone ‚Äî wield the powers of God or resist the temptations of the Devil?

The legend has inspired many great writers, musicians, and other artists. The earliest known published sources for the legend are the Wolfenb√ºttler manuscript dated about 1580-1587, and a printed chapbook (the Spies edition), intended for popular sale dated 1587. Two famous literary works on the Faust theme are Christopher Marlowe‚Äôs The Tragical History of Doctor Faustus, and Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe‚Äôs Faust.

While Goethe‚Äôs Faust has been called the definitive Faust, there is no one Faust story, instead, there are hundreds or thousands of variations on the theme in theatre, music, film, poetry, art, and literature including classics and favorites: The Sorcerer‚Äôs Apprentice, The Picture of Dorian Grey, The Phantom of the Opera/Paradise, The Devil and Daniel Webster, Damn Yankees, The Little Shop of Horrors and many more.

prompt: Please give me numbered instructions on how to grow more romaine lettuce from a single head of romaine lettuce.
messages:
[{'content': 'Please give me numbered instructions on how to grow more romaine lettuce from a single head of romaine lettuce.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': "Reusing a head of romaine lettuce to produce more romaine can be a great way to save a little money.  Begin with a healthy head of romaine lettuce. You will need to harvest carefully following the steps below:
1. Leaving about 2-3 inches from the bottom of the heart, cut off the lettuce that you will use for your salad.
2. Place the freshly cut stem in a bowl with about 3 inches of water.
3. Find a bright, sunny spot to keep your lettuce project.
4. Change the water in the bowl at least every other day.
5. Watch for new roots! It could take several weeks to see these.
6. Monitor your new roots. Once you have roots that are 2 inches long, it's time to plant your lettuce in the soil!
7. You have your choice of planting options; either a raised bed or a pot.
8. Plant your lettuce in your preferred location, ensuring that the roots are completely covered.
9. Water regularly (several times per week), and watch your FREE lettuce grow!

Once your lettuce is ready for harvest, you can take only the outermost leaves and allow the center to continue to grow. Or, you can cut the head off just above the stem, leaving the root system intact. Free lettuce over and over again!
 ", 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: Write a short informative piece about heartworm infection in dogs
messages:
[{'content': 'Write a short informative piece about heartworm infection in dogs', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': 'Heartworm infection is a serious disease that has the potential to result in organ damage, heart failure, severe lung disease, and death. Dogs residing in areas with high populations of mosquitos, which carry infectious heartworm larvae to new hosts, are at risk of infection from heartworms. 

Heartworm infection presents with various symptoms, including a mild yet persistent cough, weight loss, fatigue, decreased appetite, and exercise reluctance. As the infection progresses, dogs may develop swollen bellies due to excessive fluid and heart failure. 

The best way to prevent dogs from heartworm infection and disease is to test them regularly at a veterinarian and provide them with monthly heartworm prevention. ', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: I love meat but I've decided to go vegan. Give me a list of five vegan meat alternatives, but don't include any fruits and don't include tofu. I can't stand tofu.
messages:
[{'content': "I love meat but I've decided to go vegan. Give me a list of five vegan meat alternatives, but don't include any fruits and don't include tofu. I can't stand tofu.", 'role': 'user'}, {'content': '1. Seitan - Made from wheat protein, seitan is a popular meat substitute among vegans. Wheat flour dough is rinsed until all of the starch is gone, leaving the gluten. After this, it's steamed, boiled, or baked to give it a meaty texture. Seitan is widely used in vegan deli meats and chicken substitutes.

2. Green Spelt - Another wheat-based substitute, green spelt is spelt grain that's harvested while it's partially ripe. It's then roasted and dried, giving it a strong flavor. Green spelt is easy to digest and contains lots of B vitamins, phosphorus, and magnesium, and is used often in vegan meatballs, among other products.

3. Oat Flakes - Rich in zinc and iron, they're relatively cheap and available at virtually any supermarket. Oat flakes are made into a dough, fried, and added to vegetable broth, fat, carrots or zucchini, and other proteins. They're also a great source of complex carbohydrates, giving you more of that "full" feeling after a meal.

4. Black Beans - Black beans are commonly used for vegan burger patties, providing a tasty and nutritious alternative to restaurants and store-bought patties. They're rich in protein and fiber and the skins contain powerful antioxidants.

5. Chickpeas - Chickpeas are widely used as an alternative to chicken and turkey. They're incredibly protein dense and contain significant amounts of iron, calcium, and fiber. Mashed chickpeas can be mixed with breadcrumbs for tasty vegan nuggets, and they're great on pasta in a vegan meat sauce.', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: Are balloons bad for the environment?
messages: [{'content': 'Are balloons bad for the environment?', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': 'Even though latex balloons biodegrade in six months to four years, in the meantime, they may be mistaken for food by wildlife. Ingesting the balloons may cause serious ill effects or death. Getting caught in the balloon string can be harmful as well. If a mylar balloon touches power lines, it may cause short circuits, power outages, and fires.', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt:
Explain this same concept, but do so in a way that a 5th grader can understand.

Melissa Murray: Let‚Äôs start with the elephant in the room: the mifepristone rulings. A judge in the Amarillo division of the northern district of Texas has issued a decision that stays the FDA‚Äôs approval of mifepristone. Another competing ruling in the western district of Washington requires the FDA to continue making mifepristone available to those in a number of blue states which have filed a challenge of their own to maintain mifepristone access. We have governors in states like California and Massachusetts stockpiling both mifepristone and misoprostol. Is it chaotic by design?

Jessica Valenti: Yes. The point is to sow so much uncertainty that even in places where abortion is legal, people don‚Äôt know if they can get the care they are legally entitled to. Doctors will be afraid. Pharmacists will be afraid. And because this is all changing so quickly, that feeds into that chaos too.

Melissa Murray: In June 2022, the Supreme Court issued its much-anticipated decision in Dobbs, which upheld by a 6-3 vote a Mississippi law that banned abortion at just 15 weeks‚Äîand by a 5-4 vote, overruled both Casey and Roe. The Court insisted that its decision did no more than return the fraught and vexed question of abortion to the democratic process and to the people, who were rightfully the ones to decide this question. So, is Judge Kacsmaryk ‚Äúthe people‚Äù?

Jessica Valenti: We always knew that it was never about state‚Äôs rights. It was always about banning abortion in every single state in every possible way.

What has been really frustrating to me in Kacsmaryk‚Äôs ruling is this idea that they‚Äôre doing something for women‚Äôs health, that they‚Äôre protecting us. It just adds salt to the wound. It makes me a little more furious than usual because it‚Äôs so offensive, so insulting and so obviously false.

Melissa Murray: What Jessica is referring to is the plaintiff, the Alliance for Hippocratic Medicine, arguing that mifepristone is unsafe for women despite the FDA‚Äôs approval that has been in place for over 20 years. What is this about? Is this a backlash to women‚Äôs progress? Is this an effort to put us back into a particular box? I mean the women‚Äôs rights movement has been in place since the 1970s. Ruth Bader Ginsburg helped to read women into the Equal Protection Clause. Abortion rights is only part of that. Again, this is the question this symposium asks: Is there more to come, and how will we as women fit into a society that purports to be democratic without necessarily taking into account the voices of women?

Jessica Valenti: I think so much of this is about punishment. I don‚Äôt think it is a coincidence that they went after abortion medication specifically. Abortion medication completely changed the way that people were able to get abortion care. You can have an abortion in your home while watching Netflix privately. We took away their ability to publicly shame us at clinics, and that made them angry. They don‚Äôt want abortion to be easy and safe and that is part of the big hypocrisy.

Melissa Murray: Punishing women but for what? What are we doing?

Jessica Valenti: Existing. Having our own lives and making our own decisions. And I think with abortion specifically that is very much you controlling your body, the trajectory of your life and of your family.

prompt: Do eggs contain high amounts of cholesterol? If so, do eggs have a lot of vitamins to balance it out?
messages: [{'content': 'Do eggs contain high amounts of cholesterol? If so, do eggs have a lot of vitamins to balance it out?', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': 'Eggs have high amounts of dietary cholesterol, with one large egg offering 200 grams. However, research shows that fats in your diet affect your cholesterol levels more than cholesterol in food. The food that you eat alongside your eggs also affects your health--sliced avocados and grilled tomatoes are lighter options than bacon and sausage. Additionally, eggs are a good source of protein, vitamin A, biotin, choline, and antioxidants. These nutrients boost your immune system and heighten your energy levels.', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt:
Reframe this discussion about the perceived effectiveness of supplements, with a particular focus on Vitamin D, into a conversation between two health-conscious friends debating about the validity of supplements in their daily routines.

These are dark days for supplements. Although they are a $30-plus billion market in the United States alone, vitamin A, vitamin C, vitamin E, selenium, beta-carotene, glucosamine, chondroitin, and fish oil have now flopped in study after study.

If there was one supplement that seemed sure to survive the rigorous tests, it was vitamin D. People with low levels of vitamin D in their blood have significantly higher rates of virtually every disease and disorder you can think of: cancer, diabetes, obesity, osteoporosis, heart attack, stroke, depression, cognitive impairment, autoimmune conditions, and more. The vitamin is required for calcium absorption and is thus essential for bone health, but as evidence mounted that lower levels of vitamin D were associated with so many diseases, health experts began suspecting that it was involved in many other biological processes as well.

And they believed that most of us weren‚Äôt getting enough of it. This made sense. Vitamin D is a hormone manufactured by the skin with the help of sunlight. It‚Äôs difficult to obtain in sufficient quantities through diet. When our ancestors lived outdoors in tropical regions and ran around half naked, this wasn‚Äôt a problem. We produced all the vitamin D we needed from the sun.

But today most of us have indoor jobs, and when we do go outside, we‚Äôve been taught to protect ourselves from dangerous UV rays, which can cause skin cancer. Sunscreen also blocks our skin from making vitamin D, but that‚Äôs OK, says the American Academy of Dermatology, which takes a zero-tolerance stance on sun exposure: ‚ÄúYou need to protect your skin from the sun every day, even when it‚Äôs cloudy,‚Äù it advises on its website. Better to slather on sunblock, we‚Äôve all been told, and compensate with vitamin D pills.

Yet vitamin D supplementation has failed spectacularly in clinical trials. Five years ago, researchers were already warning that it showed zero benefit, and the evidence has only grown stronger. In November, one of the largest and most rigorous trials of the vitamin ever conducted‚Äîin which 25,871 participants received high doses for five years‚Äîfound no impact on cancer, heart disease, or stroke.
messages:
[{'content': 'Reframe this discussion about the perceived effectiveness of supplements, with a particular focus on Vitamin D, into a conversation between two health-conscious friends debating about the validity of supplements in their daily routines.

These are dark days for supplements. Although they are a $30-plus billion market in the United States alone, vitamin A, vitamin C, vitamin E, selenium, beta-carotene, glucosamine, chondroitin, and fish oil have now flopped in study after study.

If there was one supplement that seemed sure to survive the rigorous tests, it was vitamin D. People with low levels of vitamin D in their blood have significantly higher rates of virtually every disease and disorder you can think of: cancer, diabetes, obesity, osteoporosis, heart attack, stroke, depression, cognitive impairment, autoimmune conditions, and more. The vitamin is required for calcium absorption and is thus essential for bone health, but as evidence mounted that lower levels of vitamin D were associated with so many diseases, health experts began suspecting that it was involved in many other biological processes as well.

And they believed that most of us weren‚Äôt getting enough of it. This made sense. Vitamin D is a hormone manufactured by the skin with the help of sunlight. It‚Äôs difficult to obtain in sufficient quantities through diet. When our ancestors lived outdoors in tropical regions and ran around half naked, this wasn‚Äôt a problem. We produced all the vitamin D we needed from the sun.

But today most of us have indoor jobs, and when we do go outside, we‚Äôve been taught to protect ourselves from dangerous UV rays, which can cause skin cancer. Sunscreen also blocks our skin from making vitamin D, but that‚Äôs OK, says the American Academy of Dermatology, which takes a zero-tolerance stance on sun exposure: ‚ÄúYou need to protect your skin from the sun every day, even when it‚Äôs cloudy,‚Äù it advises on its website. Better to slather on sunblock, we‚Äôve all been told, and compensate with vitamin D pills.

Yet vitamin D supplementation has failed spectacularly in clinical trials. Five years ago, researchers were already warning that it showed zero benefit, and the evidence has only grown stronger. In November, one of the largest and most rigorous trials of the vitamin ever conducted‚Äîin which 25,871 participants received high doses for five years‚Äîfound no impact on cancer, heart disease, or stroke.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': '"Hey Sarah, have you noticed that supplements seem to be losing their shine lately?" John asked, glancing at the array of vitamin bottles on the kitchen counter. "You know, vitamin A, C, E, even fish oil, they all seem to be failing in these research studies."

Sarah, stirring her morning coffee, nodded. "I did notice that, but it was really surprising about Vitamin D. It seemed like a sure bet, you know?"

"Yeah," John agreed. "I mean, people with lower Vitamin D levels have a higher risk of pretty much every disease you can think of - cancer, diabetes, obesity, heart diseases... the list goes on. It's also crucial for bone health because it helps absorb calcium."

Sarah furrowed her brow in thought. "And because Vitamin D is produced by our skin through sun exposure, experts believed we weren't getting enough, especially with our modern indoor lifestyles and the whole skin cancer scare leading to excessive sunscreen use." 

"Exactly!" John exclaimed. "But despite our logical assumptions, Vitamin D supplements have shown no significant benefits in clinical trials. Five years ago, researchers already began questioning its effectiveness, and recent evidence only strengthens their skepticism."

Sarah looked thoughtful. "That's concerning, considering how many people rely on these supplements. I mean, remember that large trial conducted recently? The one with over 25,000 participants receiving high Vitamin D doses for five years? It found no impact on cancer, heart disease, or stroke."

John nodded, his gaze returning to the line-up of vitamin bottles. "It definitely makes you wonder about the validity of including supplements in our daily routines, doesn't it?"', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: Write a short story describing the discovery of a Green Lantern Ring by a random bystander. Write it in the style of Kevin Smith or Grant Morrison.
messages:
[{'content': 'Write a short story describing the discovery of a Green Lantern Ring by a random bystander. Write it in the style of Kevin Smith or Grant Morrison.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': 'Clay eventually stopped cowering, slowly unfolding himself from his fetal position on the ground. The sound of crashing metal and exploding pavement quickly faded into the sound of smoldering. A brilliant green light cast itself from behind the now-ruined mailbox, shreds of former letters and packages smoking on the ground and floating slowly down on a gust of wind. 

Pulling himself back up to a standing position and checking to make sure that no one saw his temporary cowardice, the young man slowly crept up on the glow, a small voice in the back of his mind worrying at him about radiation and Marie Curie. Instead, what looked like a square plastic (or maybe ceramic? or steel?) container sat in the remains of the mailbox, nearly cracked in two, the green light spilling out. "If it's radioactive, then I'm already boned," he mused, ignoring the nagging, fearful voice of "reason."

A small green ring. Neat. Like one of those Green Lantern ones. Is it a Power Ring? "There's no way. Literally no way," he thought, followed by, "Stop saying literally all the time. Ugh." He slid the ring onto his hand without a single thought. A moment later, the form of a giant blue old man loomed above him, imposing itself over the real world. 

"Zuvan Sur?" the man said.

"Sorry, no. I'm not him. I'm Clay." 

"Clay. That sounds human. Earth." Was the old man grimacing? "Again." Yep, and there's his hand, over his face. "Again. What is even‚ÄîI take it you're from Earth?"

"Yeah, where should I be from?"

"You should be from Ungara and your name should be Zuvan Sur. But you're Clay. Okay. We did it before. Right. Yes, that's a Power Ring, and yes, that makes you a provisional Green Lantern. Please stand by while we send someone to bring you in and get you up to speed, I guess."

"Wait, whoa! Do I get a say in this?" Clay's left hand instinctively clawed at the ring on his right.

"Eventually, sure. But right now, we need to deal with this. See you soon." The image fades, leaving the real world, and a quickly approaching Green Lantern sporting bright red sidecut hair, for poor Clay to consider.', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: Write a recipe for a pink donut like the one on The Simpsons. Make it vegan! List the ingredients first and then the instructions. I'm also allergic to oats so don't use oat milk.
messages:
[{'content': "Write a recipe for a pink donut like the one on The Simpsons. Make it vegan! List the ingredients first and then the instructions. I'm also allergic to oats so don't use oat milk.", 'role': 'user'}, {'content': "Donuts:

- 2 cups all-purpose flour
- 1/2 cup granulated sugar
- 2 teaspoons baking powder
- 1/2 teaspoon baking soda
- 1/2 teaspoon salt
- 3/4 cup unsweetened almond milk
- 1/4 cup melted coconut oil
- 2 teaspoons apple cider vinegar
- 1 teaspoon vanilla extract

Pink glaze:

- 2 cups powdered sugar
- 1/4 cup unsweetened almond milk
- 1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract
- Pink food coloring 

Instructions:

1. Preheat your oven to 350¬∞F (175¬∞C) and grease a donut pan with coconut oil or non-stick spray.
2. In a large mixing bowl, whisk together the flour, granulated sugar, baking powder, baking soda, and salt until well combined.
3. In a separate bowl, combine the almond milk, melted coconut oil, apple cider vinegar, and vanilla extract. Stir well.
4. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and mix until just combined. Avoid overmixing.
5. Add a few drops of pink food coloring to the batter and stir until the color is evenly distributed. Keep adding food-colored for your desired shade of pink!
6. Spoon the batter into a piping bag or a ziplock bag with a corner snipped off. Pipe the batter into the prepared donut pan, filling each cavity about two-thirds full.
7. Place the donut pan in the preheated oven and bake for 12-15 minutes. If you can insert a toothpick and it comes out clean, you're good!
8. While the donuts are baking, prepare the pink glaze. In a medium-sized bowl, whisk together the powdered sugar, almond milk, and vanilla extract until smooth and well combined. Add a few drops of pink food coloring and mix until the glaze is pink. Add more for a deeper shade of pink!
9. Once the donuts have cooled slightly, remove them from the pan and dip each one into the pink glaze, making sure to coat both sides. Place the glazed donuts on a wire rack set over a baking sheet to allow any excess glaze to drip off.
10. If desired, you can sprinkle some vegan-friendly sprinkles or edible glitter on top of the glaze for extra decoration.
11. Let the glaze set for about 10-15 minutes before serving. ", 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt:
Rewrite this in a format a fourth grader would understand.

With Their Knowledge Combined, Two Scholars Are Deciphering a Long-Lost Native Language

When historian Alejandra Dubcovsky was in graduate school in the early 2000s, she decided to focus her research on the Indigenous cultures of the Americas. ‚ÄúI asked my professors, ‚ÄòShould I learn any Native languages?‚Äô‚Äù Dubcovsky recalled. ‚ÄúAnd they were like, ‚ÄòWhy? You know Spanish, you know French‚Äîyou‚Äôre set for life.‚Äô‚Äù Dubcovsky laughed. ‚ÄúAnd I went to Berkeley!‚Äù

Dubcovsky‚Äôs teachers were just repeating what their own mentors had told them: Native languages were too hard to learn, and most pre-Columbian cultures didn‚Äôt leave behind written records anyway. Some, like the Aztec and Maya, had hieroglyphic systems, but those symbols offered little insight into the spoken languages themselves. Why shouldn‚Äôt Dubcovsky, who was born in Argentina, just study the records of Spanish colonizers the way generations before her had done?

When she connected with Aaron Broadwell, a linguistics professor at the University of Florida, she found the missing puzzle pieces she had been seeking. Broadwell was an expert on the Native languages of the American Southeast‚ÄîChoctaw, Creek and others that belonged to the Muskogee family. His most ambitious project was decoding a language, spoken by the Timucua people, that is unrelated to any other known tongue.

When Spanish colonizers arrived in the 16th century, Timucua was the most widely spoken language in large swaths of Florida and Georgia. Within two centuries, by the time of U.S. independence, its speakers had all been enslaved, felled by disease or absorbed into other language groups. Despite its diminishment, Timucua left a record‚Äîit was the first Native language within modern U.S. borders to be put into writing, albeit using the Roman alphabet. Rare book libraries hold Franciscan texts that display Spanish on one side and Timucua on the other. Most historians just read the Spanish side. But Dubcovsky wanted to know what the Timucua texts really said.

Since around 2000, Broadwell has been assembling the first comprehensive online Timucua dictionary, with the help of graduate students and computer programs that can search for patterns in grammar and meaning. Together, he and Dubcovsky have also made a number of startling new discoveries that challenge the usual narrative about how the Timucua language came to be written down.

Those of us at Smithsonian repeated a version of that narrative in our March issue, briefly crediting the Franciscan missionary Francisco Pareja with transcribing the Timucua language into the Roman alphabet. That version of the story, with Pareja at the center, has been widely promulgated for generations. As a catalogue entry at the Library of Congress puts it: ‚ÄúTimucuan is a dead language. Spoken by an Indigenous tribe that lived in northeast-north central Florida during the time of Spanish colonization, it was learned and recorded by Friar Francisco Pareja, a missionary and self-taught linguist. Thanks to his efforts, Timucua is now considered the best-attested language from a Native tribe in Spanish Colonial Florida.‚Äù

prompt: Write a short same-sex positive story about a documentary about the 1940s translation of the Bible rephrasing a verse on homosexuality
messages:
[{'content': 'Write a short same-sex positive story about a documentary about the 1940s translation of the Bible rephrasing a verse on homosexuality', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': '1946: The Mistranslation That Shifted Culture is a feature documentary that answers the question: what if the word ‚Äúhomosexual‚Äù was never meant to be in the Bible?

The documentary follows researchers who followed the origins of the anti-gay movement in Christianity and traced it to a mistranslation in 1946. The word "homosexual" did not appear in the Bible until 1946, with a new edition of the Bible called the Revised Standard Version, or RSV.

The documentary brings to light new revelations from archives at Yale University that cast doubt on biblically-based prejudice against LGBTQIA+ people. Homophobia in the church has been addressed by other documentaries. What makes 1946 stand apart from others is its addressing of the specific issue at hand, which is Biblical Literalism.

It's a challenging and inspiring documentary sure to create a new wave for the Christian church going forward.', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt:

Luke: That's a fascinating query. To me, open communication is essential. Without worrying about criticism or reprisal, both partners should be able to share their thoughts, wants, and worries. It's critical to establish a safe environment where all parties feel heard and valued.

Joan: I completely agree. Any effective relationship is built on communication. In addition to chatting, participants should pay attention to one another. Understanding and empathizing with our partner's point of view can assist avoid misunderstandings and foster trust.

Luke: Without a doubt. A crucial component is trust. A solid basis of trust is created through being trustworthy and sincere with one another. maintaining our word entails being open and trustworthy, as well as maintaining our promises. Both parties can feel safe and supported because trust is the foundation of emotional intimacy.

Joan.: I concur wholeheartedly. Empathic closeness and trust are mutually beneficial. We may connect on a deeper level with one another when we feel comfortable and supported. Strengthening the emotional bond and fostering growth both as a relationship and as individuals comes from sharing our hopes, anxieties, and weaknesses.

Luke: Maintaining your individuality is equally as crucial as developing emotional intimacy. Our personal interests are essential.

prompt: In character as a brilliant but totally mad scientist, can you give me a baking recipe for coconut bundt cake? When you write the ingredients, write it in a list where the part of the cake the ingredient is for is numbered and then the ingredients are listed with lowercase letters. Write the step by step instructions in a bulleted list.
messages:
[{'content': 'In character as a brilliant but totally mad scientist, can you give me a baking recipe for coconut bundt cake? When you write the ingredients, write it in a list where the part of the cake the ingredient is for is numbered and then the ingredients are listed with lowercase letters. Write the step by step instructions in a bulleted list.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': "Mua ha ha ha ha! They may think I'm mad, but I will give you the greatest coconut bundt cake recipe ever created!

First, make sure that you have a bundt pan. This recipe is perfectly calculated for a 6-cup pan to make two cakes, but you can use one 12-cup pan to make one larger cake as long as you increase the overall cook time to an hour.

Here are the ingenious ingredients that will make a cake so good the world will think you're an evil genius like me:

1. Cake Ingredients
    a. 2 teaspoons of coconut extract. This is the most important one!
    b. 1 teaspoon of baking powder
    c. 4 eggs
    d. 2 1/4 cups of flour
    e. 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract
    f. 1/2 a cup of milk
    g. 1 cup of sweetened shredded coconut
    h. 2 1/2 cups of sugar
    i. 1/2 a teaspoon of salt
    j. 1 cup of butter (softened)
2. Glaze ingredients
   a. 1 1/2 cups of powdered sugar
   b. 1 teaspoon of coconut extract
   c. 2 tablespoons of milk
   d. 2 tablespoons of melted butter
3. Topping ingredients
   a. 2/3 a cup of shredded sweetened coconut

Now that you have gathered the ingredients for your cooking experiment, it is time to begin bringing your creation to life! Mua ha ha ha ha!

- Preheat your oven to 325 degrees F. Grease and lightly flour your bundt pans and set up your oven rack in the middle of the oven. Setting up all of this in advance separates normal scientists from true mad scientists!
- Whisk your flour, baking powder, and salt in a medium mixing bowl and set it aside.
- In a bigger mixing bowl, beat the butter and sugar together until they are fluffy and light. Add the eggs and two types of extract and continue to beat this new mixture until it is smooth. Add the milk and beat again on low speed. Then add the flour mix from the other bowl and beat it until the two have become one. Stir in your coconut.
- Pour this batter into your bundt pans and put them in the oven for fifty to fifty-five minutes. You should have plenty of time to plot your next experiment while you're waiting!
- When your cake is finished, set the pan on a wire rack to cool for fifteen minutes. After this, place the cooling rack over the top of the pan and flip the whole thing over. The cake should drop out with no problem if you have followed my brilliant instructions correctly!
- Now, the time of the glaze has arrived. Melt the butter in a glass bowl, then add the rest of the three ingredients and whisk it all together until it is smooth. Add more milk to thin it or more powdered sugar to thicken it.
- Drizzle the glaze and sprinkle the coconut over the cake, and your experiment is finally alive! Cackle aggressively to mark your success and enjoy your cake.", 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt:
Rewrite this as if it's a speech being given by someone in a board meeting, looking for the team to get results.

It has been a little over a year since Batwoman was cancelled by The CW, bringing the fan-favorite superhero series to a close after three seasons. The second and third seasons of the show were led by Javicia Leslie, who brought the new character of Ryan Wilder / Batwoman to life, and charmed many fans in the process. In the time since Batwoman's cancellation, Leslie has gotten to reprise her role (with a twist) on the ninth and final season of The Flash, but it sounds like there's even more that she would love to tackle with regards to the character. While speaking to ComicBook.com about her role in the upcoming film Double Life, Leslie touched on what she would want to tackle if she got the opportunity to portray Ryan again.

"Definitely more stunts," Leslie explained. "I think that Ryan's fighting sequences are really great, because she's not a superhero, so it's not really... I mean, she's a superhero. She doesn't have magic powers, so it's not like she's like, 'Da da da da.' It's fight scenes, and I love that. I love the fight sequences. I would just [want] more Gotham. I would love to explore more Gotham. Instead of putting her somewhere else, what else can we do in Gotham? Gotham is such a cool world, and it's a world that I grew up reading and watching and being entertained by. So I think there's still so much to play with in that world."

prompt: write me a story about a person who discovers they have the ability to talk to animals, and how this changes their life.
messages:
[{'content': 'write me a story about a person who discovers they have the ability to talk to animals, and how this changes their life.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': 'David Mahone was a regular boy who lived in the rural areas of England. He lived with his parents, John Mahone and Lisa Monroe. David loved to go outside and explore the countryside, which was full of lush fields of crops and animals. In the distance, there was always a forest, which his parents always told him not to enter because there were poisonous plants and vicious animals. David being a curious kid, decided he was grown enough to 'challenge the almighty jungle' not knowing what awaited him.

After school on an odd Thursday afternoon, he ventured into the forest without telling his parents. As he entered, the atmosphere almost changed from thick fog to a more visible and bright environment. He suddenly heard loud voices, which sounded like they came from a human. He decided to check the sound out, thinking it was another group of kids who were also curious. He walked through the forest, being cautious and amazed by the scenery. 

All of a sudden, he saw what looked like a monkey sleeping on the ground. Being curious, he decided to try to poke it with a stick. "What are you doing," screamed the monkey. David had never seen a monkey before, especially not a talking monkey. "Were you sleeping?" asked David. "No, I've hurt my left foot," replied the monkey. David was still in shock to hear a monkey talk but, surprisingly, he did not take it too seriously. 

David decided to help the monkey with its injury, even though the monkey looked hostile, because it was clearly a person like David who had hurt it. After a few minutes, the monkey felt better and thanked David for his assistance. The monkey later explained what happened in the forest and how he injured his left foot. 

David heard the story and was left in tears to hear what humans had done to the monkey and the other animals in the forest. He later learned that his parents also contributed to this monstrosity. Learning this, David felt a little angry towards his parents, but he was happy he was able to find out the truth. Then, the monkey said, "You are the chosen one."', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt:
Summarize for me in a few sentences what the release process for Toki will be like. 

Tokitae, or Toki, the oldest killer whale in captivity, will finally be released to her "home waters" in Puget Sound, off Washington State. The 57-year-old orca, nicknamed Lolita, was captured when she was four and sold to the Miami Seaquarium in Florida. She entertained park visitors for over five decades before retiring in 2022.

The 5,000-pound (2,267-kg), 20-foot-long (6 meters) orca has spent most of her life in a tiny tank. It measures 80 feet by 35 feet (24 meters by 11 meters) and 20 feet (6 meters) deep!
The news of the killer whale's release was announced on March 30, 2023. Toki will be reintroduced to the wild gradually. She will begin her new life in a netted 15-acre (6-hectare) whale sanctuary built in the waters around the San Juan Islands. The killer whale will initially be restricted to a smaller enclosure within that sanctuary and monitored closely.

If all goes well, the orca will eventually be reunited with her family. Toki is believed to be the daughter of the 89-year-old leader of the L-pod. This is one of three groups that make up the Southern Resident killer whales. The endangered orcas live in the Salish Sea between Washington State and British Columbia. As of July 2021, only 73 Southern Residents remain.

Though hailed as a victory by animal activists, Toki's former caregivers are not thrilled about the killer whale's release. They believe the animal is in poor health and the stress of the move, which could take multiple days, might kill her. She could also be susceptible to pollutants in the ocean waters.

Instead, they suggest keeping her in Florida. One option is to move her to SeaWorld Orlando. The marine zoological park has one of the largest killer whale habitats in the world. They also have the expertise to provide the care Toki needs. Additionally, the move would take only a few hours. This would be less traumatic for the killer whale.

prompt: Write a short story, intended for children, that is composed in a style mimicking a Dr. Seuss book and that has a subject matter involving endangered species and wildlife conservation. Do this in 200 words or less.
messages:
[{'content': 'Write a short story, intended for children, that is composed in a style mimicking a Dr. Seuss book and that has a subject matter involving endangered species and wildlife conservation. Do this in 200 words or less. ', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': "There once was a place called Earth, that kept filling with humans, birth after birth, 
Because humans got to be so many, other animals began disappearing in numbers of plenty.
Too much time had gone by and it's a waste, how humanity caused so many species to become displaced. 

And displaced isn't the only thing some creatures became, some vanished overnight and humanity was mostly to blame.
Accountability needed to be claimed, and making things right for these species harmed was a goal for which humanity must aim.
Creatures like the elephant, grey wolf, and rhino, couldn't survive humanity giving them another hard blow.

We must save the animals that we harmed and restore the environment we drained, for saving mother earth is anything but lame. 
Helping right our wrongs in nature would benefit us too. It's a solution to the problem of climate change, I attest this is true.
Though no one is discussing this as a solution for days growing warmer, restoring these species to their ecosystems would 
be a major climate transformer. So, children, gather around near, and one time for wildlife conservation let's do a cheer!", 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: Write a script for a YouTube video about Michael Pollan and corn. It can be in a tone that is sort of sensationalizing. Needs to be speaking to the audience, so referring to audience as ‚Äúyou‚Äù is good.
messages:
[{'content': 'Write a script for a YouTube video about Michael Pollan and corn. It can be in a tone that is sort of sensationalizing. Needs to be speaking to the audience, so referring to audience as ‚Äúyou‚Äù is good. ', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': 'Corn. It‚Äôs in everything, everywhere, forever! If you live in America, you probably eat corn on a regular basis. Even if you don‚Äôt eat corn, you‚Äôre still eating corn. Meat eaters, I‚Äôm looking at you. Most livestock in the United States are fed on corn feed. I'm definitely not the first person to talk about this! This video isn't just about corn. It's also about Michael Pollan, one of the leading food researchers and writers in America. In The Omnivore's Dilemma, he details his time traveling across America in pursuit of the truth of this cornerstone crop. In four meals, his research shows that the problems with corn go beyond just our health. 

American supermarkets are lined with more than 45,000 items that contain corn. That's not just food! Diapers, batteries, and the wax on magazines are all made of or contain corn! As I said earlier, meat also contains corn in some way! Many of the preservatives that keep our food fresh too. Our brands may be diverse, but it all leads back to corn - so much so that it can be tracked back by a chemical test by checking to see if a particular structure of carbon is present. Scientifically, if you were to test certain tissue, you'd be able to find this in American humans as well.

Eating is good for you. Corn, at a base level, is not an evil food. It cannot be "bad". However, the evidence clearly shows that American foodways involving corn have been shaping dangerous and disastrous ecological devastation around the world. ', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: Write me a javascript function that detects whether you are on a mobile browser or not please

Summarize this article by removing irrelevant information so that you only explain why cigarette ads allowed aren't on television and radio.

On April 1, 1970, President Richard Nixon signs legislation officially banning cigarette ads on television and radio. Nixon, who was an avid pipe smoker, indulging in as many as eight bowls a day, supported the legislation at the increasing insistence of public health advocates.
Alarming health studies emerged as early as 1939 that linked cigarette smoking to higher incidences of cancer and heart disease and, by the end of the 1950s, all states had laws prohibiting the sale of cigarettes to minors. In 1964, the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) agreed that advertisers had a responsibility to warn the public of the health hazards of cigarette smoking. In 1969, after the surgeon general of the United States released an official report linking cigarette smoking to low birth weight, Congress yielded to pressure from the public health sector and signed the Cigarette Smoking Act. This act required cigarette manufacturers to place warning labels on their products that stated ‚ÄúCigarette Smoking May be Hazardous to Your Health.‚Äù
By the early 1970s, the fight between the tobacco lobby and public health interests forced Congress to draft legislation to regulate the tobacco industry and special committees were convened to hear arguments from both sides. Public health officials and consumers wanted stronger warning labels on tobacco products and their advertisements banned from television and radio, where they could easily reach impressionable children. (Tobacco companies were the single largest product advertisers on television in 1969.) Cigarette makers defended their industry with attempts to negate the growing evidence that nicotine was addictive and that cigarette smoking caused cancer. Though they continued to bombard unregulated print media with ads for cigarettes, tobacco companies lost the regulatory battle over television and radio. The last televised cigarette ad ran at 11:50 p.m. during The Johnny Carson Show on January 1, 1971.
Tobacco has played a part in the lives of presidents since the country‚Äôs inception. A hugely profitable crop in early America, Presidents Washington, Jefferson, Madison and Jackson owned tobacco plantations and used tobacco in the form of snuff or smoked cigars. Regulation of the tobacco industry in the form of excise taxes began during Washington‚Äôs presidency and continues to this day. In 1962, John F. Kennedy became the first president to sponsor studies on smoking and public health.
Tobacco has not been the only thing smoked at the White House. In 1978, after country-music entertainer Willie Nelson performed for President Carter there, he is said to have snuck up to the roof and surreptitiously smoked what he called a big fat Austin torpedo, commonly known as marijuana.

prompt: Give me a list of the best coffee shops in Oklahoma City. I am lactose intolerant, so I prefer non-dairy options. I also enjoy unique and different locations. Starbucks is not an option.
messages:
[{'content': 'Give me a list of the best coffee shops in Oklahoma City. I am lactose intolerant, so I prefer non-dairy options. I also enjoy unique and different locations. Starbucks is not an option.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': "Here is a list of some of the unique and high-quality coffee shops in Oklahoma City. Each of these is unique from the other, and not one is the same as the other. 

1. Coffee Slingers. Coffee Slingers is a famous Uptown coffee shop that many business professionals love to gather at for fun business meetings. It is also a fantastic location to study or work remotely, and they have plenty of sitting for groups or just individuals. The coffee is fresh and roasted within the coffee shop itself, which helps keep their product always fresh and new. They also have non-dairy options such as oat milk and soy milk options. If you are looking for a shop mixed with class and rustic merged, this is a great location. 

2. Elemental Coffee. Elemental has the best ambiance that expresses Oklahoma City the best. With a twist of industrial and hipster aesthetics, this coffee shop gives a unique look. Elemental also has some of the best intense espresso options, which are helpful for those who need a good pick-me-up in the morning or after lunch. Elemental also provides non-dairy options, although their coffee without added milk or sugar is full of flavor on its own. 

3. The Red Cup. If you are someone who is looking for something extremely unique and nothing like any other coffee shop, the Red Cup is the best. With a mix of edgy and grandma's farmhouse, Red Cup gives a fun aesthetic that you will never find in any other coffee shop. Along with this, Red Cup also serves breakfast options including Vegan/Vegetarian foods with tofu and soy-based protein. This is a great place to go to meet a friend for a long chat or just looking to have a great morning coffee. 

4. Clarity. Clarity is a perfect coffee shop for those looking for a pick-me-up in Midtown. Not only do they have great quality coffee, but everyone talks about how great the location is. This is a perfect location for those looking for their first Oklahoma CIty experience, or if you are just taking a break from work from the Business Center. They also offer many different non-dairy options, which is a big plus for those who are lactose intolerant. ", 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: Answer this question like you're a philosopher: Why do I have to eat my vegetables?
messages: [{'content': "Answer this question like you're a philosopher: Why do I have to eat my vegetables?", 'role': 'user'}, {'content': 'When we are children, we are mostly concerned with the immediate good: what can be of benefit to us within the next thirty minutes or so. Part of this comes from our lack of object permanence or finality, but part of this is because we are selfish creatures at heart. I say, however, that it is not for us to become unselfish, but rather to become selfish in a more fundamental way. Do not do the thing that causes you immediate pleasure if your future self may suffer the consequences. Do the truly selfish thing and plan only for your future. Eat your vegetables selfishly, for they will cause you to grow and mature into a healthier version of yourself. That is the truly selfish thing. ', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: Write a blog about how business owners can increase their sales. Include information about the 3 types of spenders. Give 5 proven strategies for making sales. Keep the blog below 300 words.
messages:
[{'content': 'Write a blog about how business owners can increase their sales. Include information about the 3 types of spenders. Give 5 proven strategies for making sales. Keep the blog below 300 words.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': 'Neuroscience has confirmed that we often spend until it literally hurts. The key is in understanding how much money has to be spent before we reach that threshold. There are three types of spenders:
1.	Spender One: The proverbial tightwad. He hates spending money no matter what the reason. He rarely shops. He never sees the need to spend money on anything.
2.	Spender Two: The Shopaholics. They will shop till they drop or until their credit card maxes out. Their tolerance for "spending pain" is extremely high. 
3.	Spender Three: This is the largest group. They are the middle-of-the-road, average consumers. They spend when necessary and occasionally just for fun, entertainment, or amusement. They try to stay on a budget and save whenever possible.

It doesn't take a genius to realize that the tightwads are going to be the hardest group to sell to. If you can get them to make a purchase, you can sell anything to anyone! Believe it or not, there are actually some scientifically proven ways to minimize the buying pain that tightwads, and other buyers, experience when making a purchase. These are simple but powerful tools that you can start using right away to increase sales. Try these 5 proven strategies for making sales:

‚Ä¢	Reframe your offer - Use a cost comparison to shift the consumer's perception of spending pain into a savings gain.
‚Ä¢	Bundle your products - Show the consumer how they can save more by buying more.
‚Ä¢	Offer an easy payment plan - Spending pain is softened when spread out over multiple payments.
‚Ä¢	Add free shipping - Offer a simple, straightforward price point with no hidden costs.
‚Ä¢	Offer a money-back guarantee - Give the consumer confidence that they can change their mind if they aren't satisfied. 

', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: I need help with a TV commercial for my non-profit, senior smokers which helps older people (55 plus) quit smoking. I want it to be convincing and feature real-life situations with two people who quit smoking telling the audience the effects that giving up smoking has had on their lives. I want a male and female characters to be giving monologues to the camera, also describe their appearance and give them names.
messages:
[{'content': 'I need help with a TV commercial for my non-profit, senior smokers which helps older people (55 plus) quit smoking. I want it to be convincing and feature real-life situations with two people who quit smoking telling the audience the effects that giving up smoking has had on their lives. I want a male and female characters to be giving monologues to the camera, also describe their appearance and give them names.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': '[A mid-fifties African-American woman sits on a porch swing. She has a friendly smile, blue glasses, and a white dress] 
"Hello, I'm Donna. I started smoking at 15 and just... [brief pause] never stopped. I got used to it. I graduated college. I had an amazing job which I enjoyed a lot. And back then, everybody smoked. It wasn't out of the ordinary. I remember [she laughs] I used to go out for my cigarette break and the smoking shelter was always full. But then times changed. Lots of people gave that habit up, but I didn't. And I noticed a couple of things. In my professional environment, people started looking down on me for smoking, like I was inferior to them because of my habit. Then I noticed that a lot of the time when I'd go out to smoke, I'd miss important things that were happening at work. I felt excluded and it was harming my career. So I reached out to Senior Smokers and they were amazing. They gave me all the tools and support I needed to help break my habit, and now my career is thriving again!"

[A man in his early 60s sits on a couch inside his home. He is balding with grey hair and expressive brown eyes]
"I'm Alan. I just grew up smoking, you know? I smoked, my parents smoked, and my wife smoked. But then... [his eyes fill with tears and he chokes up] she passed away. Lung cancer they said, from smoking. And you know, that should've been enough to help me stop, but it wasn't. If anything, I smoked more. But then my kids sat me down. They said they didn't want to lose me like they lost their mom. That was the real kick in the backside that I needed. They gave me the number for Senior Smokers, I gave them a call and [he smiles] they were so understanding. So helpful. It's been 2 years since I had a cigarette and [he laughs] I don't miss it at all! Now my kids and grandkids know I'll be here for them for a long time to come." 

[The screen goes black, with yellow text and voiceover reading the text]
Narrator: "It's never too late to get your life back with Senior Smokers."', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: Write about a day in the life of a factory farm chicken named Nelly. The chicken is an egg layer. She is hopelessly optimistic in a dark situation.
messages:
[{'content': 'Write about a day in the life of a factory farm chicken named Nelly. The chicken is an egg layer. She is hopelessly optimistic in a dark situation.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': 'Nelly lives on Pleasent Pasture, a farm with 5,000 egg-laying hens and no pastures. "It's a nice name," Nelly says to her dying cagemate. They live in a giant metal structure that has no access to fresh air or natural sunlight. "It could just be a rumor that there is a world beyond our walls. We can't know for sure," Nelly tells the corpse of her other cagemate, who happened to be the best conversationalist when she was living. The aroma of her rotting carcass mingled with the ammonia-saturated air suffocated their lungs and eyes.  

The view of nature might encourage a desire to escape. It was for their good that their spirit be crushed. The natural cycles of the sun might interfere with the production of eggs. Bright fluorescent lights are always on to maximize egg output. "Rest can sometimes be overrated. It's much better to be productive," stated Nelly to no one in particular. She had learned that her "pep talks" really did more to isolate her from her companions than to encourage them. She mostly encouraged herself. 

When it was difficult to eat or drink because of her mutilated beak, she reasoned that there would be more for others if she consumed less. When the stench of feces became unbearable, she convinced herself that suffering was good for producing a well-rounded character.  "Empathy could only come by means as this," she said in a sing-song voice. "Besides," she continued, "the world has enough apathetic chickens as it is." 

Nelly's wings ached from never being able to fully spread them to their capacity, but it was a small price to pay for leaving more room for others. "I don't need to stretch my wings out and flap them. I wouldn't want to be selfish when there are so many of us in here. I will try to move less so that Dolores can maybe wiggle around more. She gets a little stir-crazy sometimes. It must be cabin fever. If only everyone could just practice being a little more content."
', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt:
Use this to answer my question. What is the rating of the borrowers that advertised rates are generally for?

Nobel Prize recipient, Richard Thaler, in his research into seemingly irrational economic behaviors, "found that consumers generally search too little, get confused while evaluating complex alternatives, and are slow to switch from past choices, even if it costs them." "Why are consumers leaving money on the table?"

Based on this behavior, a borrower securing a mortgage might depend on their existing banking relationship or a single referral from a friend or agent rather than shopping multiple lenders.

When shopping for a lower mortgage rate, consider that not all lenders share the same business practices. Some may lure unsuspecting borrowers to a rate, knowing full well that they cannot deliver on it. After making a loan application and supplying information necessary for approval, they reveal that the rate is not available for "whatever" reason.

They‚Äôre counting on the borrower wanting to get into the home because the closing date is near and they‚Äôll compromise by accepting the higher than quoted rate.

Shopping for a mortgage rate can result in savings because rates are set by individual lenders. To get an apples-to-apples comparison, the terms of the mortgage being shopped should be consistent among the lender candidates.

Consumers can make additional savings by not only shopping for better rates but for better terms and fees, which can vary widely among lenders.

The amount of savings can be affected not only by the difference in rates, but the size of the mortgage and the length of time borrowers expect to keep it without refinancing or selling.

Advertised rates are generally for A++ borrowers and the determination is the lender‚Äôs based on many factors. It may be unlikely those rates are offered to you.
A recommendation for the best lender from a friend or family member will not necessarily be the best for you.
Instead of accepting the first offer received, shop for at least three to five offers.
Your personal bank may be convenient but it may not offer you the best rate, terms, and fees.
Ask if there is room to negotiate the rate or fees.
Ask your real estate professional for recommendations of several trusted lenders for you to shop a rate, terms, and fees.
messages:
[{'content': 'Use this to answer my question. What is the rating of the borrowers that advertised rates are generally for?

Nobel Prize recipient, Richard Thaler, in his research into seemingly irrational economic behaviors, "found that consumers generally search too little, get confused while evaluating complex alternatives, and are slow to switch from past choices, even if it costs them." "Why are consumers leaving money on the table?"

Based on this behavior, a borrower securing a mortgage might depend on their existing banking relationship or a single referral from a friend or agent rather than shopping multiple lenders.

When shopping for a lower mortgage rate, consider that not all lenders share the same business practices. Some may lure unsuspecting borrowers to a rate, knowing full well that they cannot deliver on it. After making a loan application and supplying information necessary for approval, they reveal that the rate is not available for "whatever" reason.

They‚Äôre counting on the borrower wanting to get into the home because the closing date is near and they‚Äôll compromise by accepting the higher than quoted rate.

Oh yeah', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': "Once upon a time, when the tigers lived and played, something woohoo-worthy and also a little scary happened. Guess what? A tiger got sick with a really bad virus called coronavirus! Tigers are usually so strong and brave, but this virus made them sick too!

This tiger, who lived in the famous Bronx Zoo in New York, got caught by this unexpected illness. It made all the animals confused and worried because they thought only humans could get sick like that. How did a wild tiger get hurt by this invisible germ? It was like a big surprise party, but not the fun kind where everyone screams Woohoo! What a strange and puzzling thing!

All the animals in the jungle started whispering and talking about the tiger's sickness. They said that he caught the virus from a zookeeper, just by being near them. It was a simple and harmless thing, but it made the tiger sick. Everyone got really scared because if the tiger could get sick, maybe they could too! 

The animals thought hard about what to do to keep the tiger safe and stop the virus from spreading. They knew they had to be very careful. Tigers don't know about washing their paws as humans do, so even a playful touch could pass the virus to others. They all stood together, the colorful and fierce tigers, to protect their friend from this mean virus. Woohoo, what a brave and united group they were!", 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: Write a story about someone trying to save red wolves.
messages:
[{'content': 'Write a story about someone trying to save red wolves.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': "One day the head nun found Hildegard holding hands with Sadie. They mercilessly threw her to the streets. As she stumbled out of town, Hildegard saw a bush rustle. She heard a growl and she braced for the danger that she anticipated. But instead, a red wolf pup came to her, bringing her a small rabbit. With food and protection, Hildegard stayed in the forest with the pack of red wolves, learning their ways. Their leader was chosen by kindness and that kindness and wisdom passed down through the ranks of the wolf pack. They seemed wiser than anyone back at the monastery.

Hildegard and the wolves roamed the Chattahoochee-Oconee National Forest. She hiked up the cold Little Sand Mountain, and up to the peaks of the North Georgia Mountains. There she learned the meaning of the balance of nature. Every path they traveled had its benefits and its dangers. They shaped the forest as they roamed, and they defended animals in need until one day when Gruffjaw didn't return home from his hunt. Hildegard took Thornbelly with her to search for the pup. She was calling to the beast when a shot cracked through the trees. Thornbelly lay still beside her.

Hunters had been hired by farmers to protect the lands. When Hildegard protested, they banished her from the lands once more. Hildegard never gave up. After marrying her wife Laura, Hildegard became an environmental researcher and advocate for the red wolves. As the days passed by, scientists discovered that red wolves were critically endangered. With only a few remaining wolves, Hildegard documented her time at the Chattahoochee-Oconee National Forest. She performed new research and determined that this land was perfect for the red wolves.

After a fierce political battle, Hildegard won. The Hattahoochee-Oconee National Forest would become one of the few preserves for the noble red wolf as researchers hoped that reintroducing them would bolster their population and save them from extinction.", 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt:
Rewrite this as if it's from a middle school student with a soccer game and a test tomorrow, who's talking to his friend about all the cool things he's learning about photosynthesis.

General characteristics
Development of the idea
The study of photosynthesis began in 1771 with observations made by the English clergyman and scientist Joseph Priestley. Priestley had burned a candle in a closed container until the air within the container could no longer support combustion. He then placed a sprig of mint plant in the container and discovered that after several days the mint had produced some substance (later recognized as oxygen) that enabled the confined air to again support combustion. In 1779 the Dutch physician Jan Ingenhousz expanded upon Priestley‚Äôs work, showing that the plant had to be exposed to light if the combustible substance (i.e., oxygen) was to be restored. He also demonstrated that this process required the presence of the green tissues of the plant.


In 1782 it was demonstrated that the combustion-supporting gas (oxygen) was formed at the expense of another gas, or ‚Äúfixed air,‚Äù which had been identified the year before as carbon dioxide. Gas-exchange experiments in 1804 showed that the gain in weight of a plant grown in a carefully weighed pot resulted from the uptake of carbon, which came entirely from absorbed carbon dioxide, and water taken up by plant roots; the balance is oxygen, released back to the atmosphere. Almost half a century passed before the concept of chemical energy had developed sufficiently to permit the discovery (in 1845) that light energy from the sun is stored as chemical energy in products formed during photosynthesis.
messages:
[{'content': "Rewrite this as if it's from a middle school student with a soccer game and a test tomorrow, who's talking to his friend about all the cool things he's learning about photosynthesis.

General characteristics
Development of the idea
The study of photosynthesis began in 1771 with observations made by the English clergyman and scientist Joseph Priestley. Priestley had burned a candle in a closed container until the air within the container could no longer support combustion. He then placed a sprig of mint plant in the container and discovered that after several days the mint had produced some substance (later recognized as oxygen) that enabled the confined air to again support combustion. In 1779 the Dutch physician Jan Ingenhousz expanded upon Priestley‚Äôs work, showing that the plant had to be exposed to light if the combustible substance (i.e., oxygen) was to be restored. He also demonstrated that this process required the presence of the green tissues of the plant.


In 1782 it was demonstrated that the combustion-supporting gas (oxygen) was formed at the expense of another gas, or ‚Äúfixed air,‚Äù which had been identified the year before as carbon dioxide. Gas-exchange experiments in 1804 showed that the gain in weight of a plant grown in a carefully weighed pot resulted from the uptake of carbon, which came entirely from absorbed carbon dioxide, and water taken up by plant roots; the balance is oxygen, released back to the atmosphere. Almost half a century passed before the concept of chemical energy had developed sufficiently to permit the discovery (in 1845) that light energy from the sun is stored as chemical energy in products formed during photosynthesis.", 'role': 'user'}, {'content': 'Omg, hey! So, remember how I have that soccer game tomorrow night? Well, I also have a test on photosynthesis tomorrow too! I‚Äôm so busy, lol! 

While I was studying, I really thought I found some interesting stuff about a guy named Priestley, and he discovered plants could actually make oxygen. In 1771 he put this mint plant and a lit candle in a box to see what would happen. Basically, because the candle has an active flame, it‚Äôs gonna use up all the air, but after a few days, he found out there was still air in the box.

Then like two years later, a dude named Ingenhousz figured that the color of plants and the sunlight were related, but the subject didn‚Äôt really get brought up again until 1782 when peeps found out oxygen was made out of a ‚Äúfixed air‚Äù (it‚Äôs really carbon dioxide). Then more than twenty years later, scientists found that plants get heavier when they suck up carbon dioxide and water and release oxygen.

1845 was the biggest year because that‚Äôs pretty much when they started using the term ‚Äúphotosynthesis‚Äù because they needed a name for turning sunlight into chemical energy. My mind was totally blown, dude!

Anyway, wish me luck tomorrow‚Ä¶fingers crossed I pass the test and win the big game. See ya!', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: Please write a blog post about some of the best foods you should eat to lose belly fat. Include foods like Apples, Barley, oats and others. Keep the tone conversational.
messages:
[{'content': 'Please write a blog post about some of the best foods you should eat to lose belly fat. Include foods like Apples, Barley, oats and others. Keep the tone conversational.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': "Get Rid of that Belly Fat with These Nutritious Foods

Losing belly fat doesn‚Äôt always mean you have to follow a restrictive diet. Sometimes, you just have to eat the right foods. Certain foods can target belly fat and support your weight loss goals. We‚Äôre discussing these foods today to help you get a flatter tummy.

*Apples
Crisp, juicy apples are a snack you can enjoy guilt-free. The high fiber content in apples keeps you feeling full longer. Its natural sugars provide a sweet treat that won't bust your diet.

*Barley
Try barley the next time you're in the mood for a grainy plate. It‚Äôs a nutty-tasting cereal grain that can reduce belly fat by keeping insulin levels low and stabilizing blood sugar.

*Capsaicin
Capsaicin is not a food per se. It‚Äôs a compound found in spicy peppers that can help boost weight loss. Capsaicin works by increasing thermogenesis. Thermogenesis is required for our bodies to burn calories and fat to generate heat. 
Try to spice up your meals and your metabolism with capsaicin. Cayenne and jalape√±o peppers have this compound, for example.

*Cardamom
Cardamom is a lot more than just a flavor addition to your chai tea--it's an aromatic and spicy powerhouse! Cardamom contains compounds that may help to boost your metabolism to increase fat burning while reducing inflammation in your body.

*Flaxseed
Flaxseed is an exceptionally underappreciated food. These seeds pack lots of fiber and omega-3 fatty acids. Fiber keeps you full for longer stretches of time. Omega-3 fatty acids can beat inflammation and improve insulin sensitivity, which means your body eventually stores less fat. 

*Oats
Most consider them a humble breakfast staple but they're also an extraordinary source of soluble fiber. Oats keep you safe from hunger pangs and improve digestion. Oats also contain resistant starch that increases fat burning and improves insulin sensitivity.

*Raspberries
These berries are easy on the stomach and a weight-loss gem. They also have a great dose of antioxidant compounds that can boost your health holistically while also targeting that stubborn belly fat.


Eat a diverse and balanced diet if you want to maintain a healthy weight. These foods that burn belly fat without sacrificing flavor and fun will fit perfectly in your weight management regimen.", 'role': 'assistant'}]
