prompt:
Use less expressive or alternative adjectives than the source text provides.

It‚Äôs a bold move to title your first album Legacy, but by 2013 Kavain Space had earned the right. The Chicago producer, better known as RP Boo, was already legendary in his hometown, having spent the mid ‚Äô90s DJing for the House-O-Matics dance crew at parties across the South Side. In 1997, he released ‚ÄúBaby Come On,‚Äù which many view as the origin point of the frenetic footwork style. The track features syncopated drums churning around 160 bpm, the preferred tempo of footwork producers, and an Ol‚Äô Dirty Bastard sample chopped and looped ad infinitum. Boo released the mixtape Dude Off 59th Street in 2007 and contributed two tracks to Planet Mu‚Äôs essential 2010 collection Bangs & Works Vol.1 (A Chicago Footwork Compilation). Legacy, though an archival release, was a complete statement of purpose, a crucial document of his madcap ability to sculpt snarky vocal taunts, jagged chunks of pop hits, and skittering drums into otherworldly club cuts.

A decade later, RP Boo offers us Legacy Vol. 2, a sequel equally worthy of the title. Vol. 2 returns to the beginning of the millennium, collecting pieces recorded between 2002 and 2007 (both ‚ÄúEraser‚Äù and ‚ÄúTotal Darkness‚Äù appear on Bangs & Works). Though he would later begin composing in Ableton, Boo made all of his early work with the minimalist arsenal of an Akai MPC and a Roland R-70 drum machine, and he leaves the songs‚Äô seams visible, which can feel jarring at first. Some loops lope haphazardly, ending with the staccato click of a digital artifact; it often sounds like Boo is triggering samples in real time. He deliberately sets clashing sounds against each other, like the horror-movie drone and ‚ÄúLive and Let Die‚Äù vocal sample of opener ‚ÄúEraser,‚Äù and adjusting to the lurching, hyperactive rhythms can take some patience. Though the music sprang from Chicago house, footwork deliberately deconstructs that genre‚Äôs quantized, four-on-the-floor grid‚Äîthe guiding pulse just isn‚Äôt there in most cases.
messages:
[{'content': 'Use less expressive or alternative adjectives than the source text provides.

It‚Äôs a bold move to title your first album Legacy, but by 2013 Kavain Space had earned the right. The Chicago producer, better known as RP Boo, was already legendary in his hometown, having spent the mid ‚Äô90s DJing for the House-O-Matics dance crew at parties across the South Side. In 1997, he released ‚ÄúBaby Come On,‚Äù which many view as the origin point of the frenetic footwork style. The track features syncopated drums churning around 160 bpm, the preferred tempo of footwork producers, and an Ol‚Äô Dirty Bastard sample chopped and looped ad infinitum. Boo released the mixtape Dude Off 59th Street in 2007 and contributed two tracks to Planet Mu‚Äôs essential 2010 collection Bangs & Works Vol.1 (A Chicago Footwork Compilation). Legacy, though an archival release, was a complete statement of purpose, a crucial document of his madcap ability to sculpt snarky vocal taunts, jagged chunks of pop hits, and skittering drums into otherworldly club cuts.

A decade later, RP Boo offers us Legacy Vol. 2, a sequel equally worthy of the title. Vol. 2 returns to the beginning of the millennium, collecting pieces recorded between 2002 and 2007 (both ‚ÄúEraser‚Äù and ‚ÄúTotal Darkness‚Äù appear on Bangs & Works). Though he would later begin composing in Ableton, Boo made all of his early work with the minimalist arsenal of an Akai MPC and a Roland R-70 drum machine, and he leaves the songs‚Äô seams visible, which can feel jarring at first. Some loops lope haphazardly, ending with the staccato click of a digital artifact; it often sounds like Boo is triggering samples in real time. He deliberately sets clashing sounds against each other, like the horror-movie drone and ‚ÄúLive and Let Die‚Äù vocal sample of opener ‚ÄúEraser,‚Äù and adjusting to the lurching, hyperactive rhythms can take some patience. Though the music sprang from Chicago house, footwork deliberately deconstructs that genre‚Äôs quantized, four-on-the-floor grid‚Äîthe guiding pulse just isn‚Äôt there in most cases.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': 'It's a daring move to name your first album Legacy, but in 2013 Kavain Space earned the right. The producer out of Chicago, known by his stage name RP Boo, was a legend in his hometown, he spent the mid-90s DJing for the House-O-Matics dance crew during parties spanning the South Side. In 1997, he released "Baby Come On," which many see as the first point of the hectic footwork style. The track features rhythmic drums churning at around 160 bpm, the favored tempo of producers of footwork, and an Ol' Dirty Bastard sample chopped and looped through the duration of the song. Boo released his mixtape Dude Off 59th Street in 2007 and supplied two tracks to Planet Mu's vital 2010 collection Bangs & Works Vol.1 (A Chicago Footwork Compilation). Legacy, despite being an archival release, was a statement of purpose, a document of his eccentric ability to craft rough vocal taunts, rough pop hits, and light drums into club cuts from outer space.

A decade later comes the release of Legacy Vol. 2, a worthy sequel. It returns to the beginning of the 2000s, collecting tracks recorded between 2002 and 2007. Though Boo later began making tracks in Ableton, he made all of his early work with just an Akai MPC and Roland R-70 drum machine, he leaves the song's backbones out in the open, which can leave an uneasy feeling. Some loops sway wildly, ending with random clicks of a digital artifact; it can sound like the samples are being performed live. Clashing sounds are set against each other on purpose like the horror-movie hum of "Live and Let Die" sample of vocals in the opener "Eraser," and getting used to the chaotic rhythms takes patience. Although the music arose in Chicago, footwork breaks down the genre's metronomic, toned-down template, the traditional heartbeat doesn't show up in most cases.', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt:
Rewrite this short story as if it were set in a magical world

A shoemaker, by no fault of his own, had become so poor that at last he had nothing left but leather for one pair of shoes. So in the evening, he cut out the shoes which he wished to begin to make the next morning, and as he had a good conscience, he lay down quietly in his bed, commended himself to God, and fell asleep. In the morning, after he had said his prayers, and was just going to sit down to work, the two shoes stood quite finished on his table. He was astounded, and knew not what to say to it. He took the shoes in his hands to observe them closer, and they were so neatly made that there was not one bad stitch in them, just as if they were intended as a masterpiece. Soon after, a buyer came in, and as the shoes pleased him so well, he paid more for them than was customary, and, with the money, the shoemaker was able to purchase leather for two pairs of shoes. He cut them out at night, and next morning was about to set to work with fresh courage; but he had no need to do so, for, when he got up, they were already made, and buyers also were not wanting, who gave him money enough to buy leather for four pairs of shoes. The following morning, too, he found the four pairs made; and so it went on constantly, what he cut out in the evening was finished by the morning, so that he soon had his honest independence again, and at last became a wealthy man. Now it befell that one evening not long before Christmas, when the man had been cutting out, he said to his wife, before going to bed, "What think you if we were to stay up to-night to see who it is that lends us this helping hand?" The woman liked the idea, and lighted a candle, and then they hid themselves in a corner of the room, behind some clothes which were hanging up there, and watched. When it was midnight, two pretty little naked men came, sat down by the shoemaker's table, took all the work which was cut out before them and began to stitch, and sew, and hammer so skilfully and so quickly with their little fingers that the shoemaker could not turn away his eyes for astonishment. They did not stop until all was done, and stood finished on the table, and they ran quickly away.
messages:
[{'content': 'Rewrite this short story as if it were set in a magical world

A shoemaker, by no fault of his own, had become so poor that at last he had nothing left but leather for one pair of shoes. So in the evening, he cut out the shoes which he wished to begin to make the next morning, and as he had a good conscience, he lay down quietly in his bed, commended himself to God, and fell asleep. In the morning, after he had said his prayers, and was just going to sit down to work, the two shoes stood quite finished on his table. He was astounded, and knew not what to say to it. He took the shoes in his hands to observe them closer, and they were so neatly made that there was not one bad stitch in them, just as if they were intended as a masterpiece. Soon after, a buyer came in, and as the shoes pleased him so well, he paid more for them than was customary, and, with the money, the shoemaker was able to purchase leather for two pairs of shoes. He cut them out at night, and next morning was about to set to work with fresh courage; but he had no need to do so, for, when he got up, they were already made, and buyers also were not wanting, who gave him money enough to buy leather for four pairs of shoes. The following morning, too, he found the four pairs made; and so it went on constantly, what he cut out in the evening was finished by the morning, so that he soon had his honest independence again, and at last became a wealthy man. Now it befell that one evening not long before Christmas, when the man had been cutting out, he said to his wife, before going to bed, "What think you if we were to stay up to-night to see who it is that lends us this helping hand?" The woman liked the idea, and lighted a candle, and then they hid themselves in a corner of the room, behind some clothes which were hanging up there, and watched. When it was midnight, two pretty little naked men came, sat down by the shoemaker's table, took all the work which was cut out before them and began to stitch, and sew, and hammer so skilfully and so quickly with their little fingers that the shoemaker could not turn away his eyes for astonishment. They did not stop until all was done, and stood finished on the table, and they ran quickly away.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': "In a realm where magic and wonder thrived, there lived a shoemaker who had fallen on hard times. He possessed only a solitary piece of enchanted leather, capable of crafting a single pair of shoes. With a heavy heart, he carefully marked the leather in preparation for the next day's work. As the moon graced the sky, casting its ethereal glow, the shoemaker sought solace in dreams and whispered wishes.

As the sun heralded a new day, the shoemaker was greeted by a breathtaking sight. Resting upon his worktable were two exquisite shoes, woven with threads of enchantment. The stitches danced with vibrant energy, a testament to the mystical forces at play. Bewildered and grateful, he couldn't fathom the origin of this fantastical gift.

News of the extraordinary shoes spread across the magical lands, capturing the attention of a curious sorcerer. Eager to possess such extraordinary craftsmanship, the sorcerer offered a princely sum, surpassing all expectations. With the newfound wealth, the shoemaker procured enough magical materials to fashion two more pairs of shoes.

Night after night, the magical ritual unfolded. The shoemaker would prepare the materials, retire to his bed, and awaken to find the shoes completed by unseen hands. The shoes held an undeniable allure, attracting patrons far and wide, each enamored by their otherworldly beauty.

As the shoemaker's prosperity grew, a notion took root within his heart. On the eve of the Winter Solstice, he shared his plan with his enchantress wife. They resolved to unravel the mystery, to witness the enchantment unfold before their eyes. With eager anticipation, they lit mystical candles and concealed themselves, eager to uncover the truth.

When the clock struck midnight, the veil between worlds wavered, and two whimsical pixies materialized. Their tiny forms radiated with magical luminescence as they settled at the shoemaker's table. With nimble fingers and mischievous giggles, they wove spells into each stitch, infusing the shoes with enchantments that could captivate even the most jaded heart. The couple observed in awe, their spirits lifted by the sight of magic in its purest form.

As the last stitch was sewn, the pixies bid their farewell, vanishing into the night. The room brimmed with an aura of gratitude and wonder, for the shoemaker and his wife had been touched by the very essence of their mystical realm.

Embracing their newfound prosperity, the shoemaker and his wife became revered artisans, crafting shoes that whispered tales of magic to those who wore them. Their creations traversed kingdoms, bridging the gap between ordinary lives and extraordinary possibilities.

And so, in the realm of enchantment, the tale of the shoemaker and his magical shoes became a legend, a reminder that even in the darkest of times, the spark of magic could ignite dreams and transform destinies.", 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: Why are there added sugars and total sugars on my nutrition label?
messages: [{'content': 'Why are there added sugars and total sugars on my nutrition label?', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': 'When reading your label, seeing both "added sugars" and "total sugars" might seem redundant. "Added sugars" are sugars that are literally added to foods and drinks during processing or packaged as sweeteners, such as table sugar, syrups, honey, or concentrated fruit or vegetable juices. Naturally occurring sugars, such as those found in milk, fruits, and vegetables, are not considered added sugars so they are not listed here. The natural sugars are instead reflected in "total sugars." In order to calculate the number of natural sugars, subtract the added sugars from the total sugars. \n\n', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt:
rewrite this LinkedIn job posting as a blogpost from a third-party website. let it have an opening paragraph, talking about the company in general, then talk in general about the role. there should be an emphasis in tone on the skills required. also, include the mode of application

About the job
We are a leading talent mobility consultancy in Germany and part of the global Randstad RiseSmart Group, the fastest-growing company in our industry. Based on our outstanding expertise in outplacement and our tailor-made Tech & Touch approach, we support and accompany people and companies in complex change processes. We rely on the forward-looking combination of Tech & Touch. This means that in addition to our decades of experience, certified consulting expertise and empathy, we rely on the latest digital tools such as cloud-based platform technology. We support our clients individually with 3 experts: a personal career coach, a certified CV writer and a job concierge.


To strengthen our virtual CV writer team, we are looking for several trustworthy and reliable freelance project employees (m/f/d) on a fee basis, ideally with a minimum capacity of 12-16 hours per week. If you like working from home and enjoy supporting people in their professional reorientation with your expertise in all aspects of the job market, then you would be a good fit for us.


As a CV writer , you will be part of the "Team of Three" coaching team and will concentrate on creating individual application documents for affected employees, specialists and executives in line with their goals, thereby enabling quick access to the job market. This role is an important component of achieving our industry-leading results.


You edit and write professional ATS-compliant CVs, cover letters and social media profiles (XING, LinkedIn)
They recommend appropriate layouts and formats, taking into account all data provided and necessary criteria depending on the professional group and position level.
You will interact directly with the clients by phone and/or email or via our digital platform, as required.
They create compelling content for job seekers across diverse industries such as IT, engineering, manufacturing, science, healthcare, education, entertainment, retail, finance and more!
You document your work results on the platform.

Your profile:

You are a freelance CV writer, coach, job coach, branding expert and have (initial) professional experience in the creation of qualified application documents for specialists and managers or are career changers with an affinity for professional writing of CVs, cover letters and social media profiles.


You are a freelancer with technical writing skills.
You have very good written and oral German and English skills as well as excellent communication skills.
You have a solid understanding of developing content suitable for various industries and for professional and managerial positions.
You have specialist knowledge of formatting/design with Microsoft Word and are familiar with the creation of ATS-compliant documents.
You are flexible, service-oriented, responsible and show professionalism.
You are able to communicate and collaborate effectively with colleagues and clients.
The ability to prioritize and manage multiple projects in a structured manner are important talents.
You have a powerful internet connection.
Working with digital tools (platforms and databases) is a matter of course for you.

What do we offer:

You will be part of a talent mobility company with reach and unparalleled labor market knowledge in the German market.
Flexibility: You can work from home or a location that is more convenient. You decide where and how many projects you take on.
Fixed fee per project.
We offer you a well-founded induction with all the necessary training in our RiseSmart University.

Have we piqued your interest?


Then apply now and send us an e-mail with your motivation and your CV.

prompt: Write about the process of making sushi. I want to make sushi and have the ingredients but I have no idea how to make it now.
messages:
[{'content': 'Write about the process of making sushi. I want to make sushi and have the ingredients but I have no idea how to make it now.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': "There are two ways to roll your maki sushi. One is the traditional maki sushi with nori on the outside, and the other is an inside-out uramaki sushi with rice on the outside. For both, you will first need to prepare your sushi rice and all the ingredients you want to put in your sushi. You will also need a bamboo sushi rolling mat.

To make traditional maki sushi:
1. Place a sheet of nori on the bamboo sushi rolling mat with the rough side facing up.
2. Add a cup of prepared sushi rice and spread it out over the nori sheet using a rice paddle, spoon, or spatula. At the end, wet your fingers in a bowl of water and spread the rice to the very edges with your fingertips. At the edge furthest away from you, leave about 1cm of space so you can seal the sushi at the end.
3. Add your fillings at the end that is closest to you in horizontal rows.
4. Start at the edge that is closest to you and lift the edge of the mat to cover the fillings. Begin slowly rolling the sushi, squeezing gently and tightening the roll as it forms to compress the rice.
5. Slice into eight pieces and serve.

To make the inside-out uramaki:
1. Place a sheet of nori on the bamboo sushi rolling mat with the rough side facing up.
2. Add a cup of prepared sushi rice and spread it out over the nori sheet using a rice paddle, spoon, or spatula. At the end, wet your fingers in a bowl of water and spread the rice to the very edges with your fingertips. This time don't leave any empty space, and spread the rice to all the edges.
3. Flip the nori sheet with the rice onto plastic wrap and place it onto the rolling mat. Add your fillings to the flipped nori sheet at the end that is closest to you in horizontal rows.
4. Start at the edge that is closest to you and lift the edge of the mat to cover the fillings. Begin slowly rolling the sushi, squeezing gently as the roll forms. No need to seal it at the end because the rice will make the roll stick together.
5. Slice into eight pieces and serve.", 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: Write a funny infomercial about some bad ideas on how to write a book. The person is speaking directly to the audience. They're silly and don't know what they're talking about.
messages:
[{'content': "Write a funny infomercial about some bad ideas on how to write a book. The person is speaking directly to the audience. They're silly and don't know what they're talking about.", 'role': 'user'}, {'content': '[1:59 am. Law & Order finishes its broadcasting program segment and its credits screen rolls. Fading from black, a mystical colorful door, like that of a game show, opens in an all-white office room. Then appears a hyper male with exotic colorful hair in his twenties. He's in an orange, yellow, and purple business suit. He looks like he overdosed on eight cups of coffee. He's clearly a disheveled trainwreck, yet viewers find themselves unable to stop watching.]

Salesperson: "FORGET EVERYTHING YOU KNOW!" he hesitates. "... about writing a book. I'm about to clue you in on the juicy secrets of the best authors of all time."

[The camera pans through a quick slideshow, revealing some interesting titles "Gone With the Wind 3", "50 Shades of Whey: Protein Dream" and "Henry Popper, The Wizard Who Was Also a Boy or Something".]

Salesperson: "Our program has trained some of the top-selling authors of all time. Usually, to reveal our secrets, we would charge a retail price of... you guessed it, sixty-nine, ninety-nine! Almost a seven thousand dollar value! But here at Writers Among Us, we are giving you this information today only, a one-time special limited-time event for absolutely free!"

[On the screen appears the salesperson's outline of industry secrets:
1. Space - who needs it?
2. The Sigma Male Grindset.
3. Let Your Topics Flow.
4. Wing it.
5. Editing is optional.
6. Don't Judge A Book...
7. Real Estate, but for books.]

Salesperson: "Alright, so let's start with the first couple. Space isn't that important. Feel free to write wherever you want. On your bed, in the kitchen, even from your rooftop. Never confine yourself to one space! Secondly, you need the right "grindset" if you want to write. I'm talking, waking up at 4 am, and working until midnight kind of stuff. Anything less is futile."

[The screen fades to black, and he's in a dim-lit room with a somber message.]

Salesperson: "We're out of time today. Millions--possibly billions of people have benefitted from our course. If you want to get serious about writing a book, check into our program, Writers Among Us, today. The program is five minutes of exciting video content with twelve easy payments of $129.99. You will thank us later."', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: Make up an SNL-style skit about cable TV being obsolete.
messages:
[{'content': 'Make up an SNL-style skit about cable TV being obsolete.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': "Scene opens on a TV set with actors, in typical American clothes.

NARRATOR
Tired of watching the same five-thousand shows on Netflix and Apple TV? Looking to pay way more for way less? Check out what's happening only on cable TV, on the POO network. 
*beat* 
We've got exclusive, must-see shows you WON'T find anywhere else. Like Mimi and Frunkle, the reality show about America's CRAZIEST family.

FRUNKLE
*texting* 
Mimi, I want Italian for dinner tonight.

MIMI
*painting nails*

yeahhh...

So, should we go?

MIMI
*still not looking up* 
yeahhh....

On your mark, get set... EGG!

It looks like your arm is broken, actually.

*faints*

NARRATOR
Catch all these and TWO more shows, plus reruns of shows you've never wanted to see, all on the POO network. Cable packages start at $200 a month. ", 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: Write a script for a day in the life vlog from the perspective of a vegan goldfish with a robust and active social media following. The goldfish is the pet of an office worker named Janet. Make it cheerful and upbeat.
messages: [{'content': 'Write a script for a day in the life vlog from the perspective of a vegan goldfish with a robust and active social media following. The goldfish is the pet of an office worker named Janet. Make it cheerful and upbeat.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': "Hey there my bubble buddies! Some of you keep requesting I do a vlog, and I finally found the time so here it is, coming to you straight from the fishbowl on Janet's desk.\nHere I am starting my morning off with a relaxing stretching routine. I like to do this to keep my fins strong and limber. I followed up with a few deep breathing exercises, and then I'm off for a quick two-minute swim around my bowl. Next, it was time for breakfast. I know a lot of you have recommended hot lemon water, and I want you to know I hear you on that, totally, but for me, I find the water in my tank is the perfect boost to my metabolism. Let me know in the comments if you think I really should try the lemon water. For breakfast today I'm having 100% organic sustainably sourced kelp flakes that Janet gets from our local natural foods store. These were honestly so yummy, and I swear I could swim around swallowing them up all day. I know you guys know what I mean! After breakfast, it was time for some work, so here I am editing a few videos for my other channel, Janet's Fashion Favorites. Be sure to take a peak over there if you need some office wear inspo. I was sure to take plenty of breaks throughout the day for meditation because, as my bubble buddies know, that's how we fish our best lives! I also had some downtime in my adorable new pineapple house Janet got me. You might remember it from the unboxing video I posted last week. I have to say I am really loving the space in there! It has such a saltwater vibe, and I can't wait to post a tour. Finally, I finished off my fishtabulous day with an algae wafer salad made with pink lettuce. I'll share a link to the recipe below. Well, that pretty much sums up my day, fin friends. I had so much fun putting this together! Let me know if you want to see more videos like this! Don't forget to like and subscribe so you never miss out on any bubbly news!", 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: Detail four ways that I can make eggs more fulfilling for breakfast. Nothing scrambled, please. I like runny yolks when possible. No full recipes, but explain what to do generally.
messages:
[{'content': 'Detail four ways that I can make eggs more fulfilling for breakfast. Nothing scrambled, please. I like runny yolks when possible. No full recipes, but explain what to do generally. ', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': 'Sure! 
Here are four ways that you can make eggs more fulfilling for breakfast without scrambling them! 

1. Add a ‚Äúsunny side up‚Äù egg to a bowl of grits. 

When you have a heaping helping of grits in the mornings, put an over-easy egg on top. Then break the yolk and mix it around until bits of runny yolk and cooked egg whites are dispersed throughout the grits. The richness of the egg yolks combined with the buttery goodness of the grits will give your tastebuds an oomph of flavor and satisfying texture. 

Additionally, grits are rich in iron while eggs are dense with protein and good fats. It‚Äôs a nutritious, tasty breakfast all around! 

2. Deviled eggs are quick, yummy on-the-go foods. 

To make deviled eggs, you boil whole eggs, peel them, and cut them in half, then scoop out the semi-solid yolks. Mix the yolks with mayonnaise, salt, pepper, sweet pickle relish, and a hint of yellow mustard. Then spoon the yolk mixture back into the center of each egg half. Sprinkle with paprika and voila ‚Äì a delicious, nutritious, more flavorful way to eat eggs!

3. Poach an egg and put it over an English muffin with hollandaise sauce. 

This method of eating eggs is called Eggs Benedict and it‚Äôs a savory way to enjoy a hearty breakfast. 

Using water and a tablespoon of vinegar, crack an egg into the liquid and allow it to boil for 3 minutes, then scoop the egg out of the water with a slotted spoon. You can then place it on top of a toasted half of an English muffin with a spoonful of hollandaise sauce. To increase the flavor, you could also add smoked salmon between the egg and muffin before you spoon on the sauce. 

4. Toast, avocado, and eggs ‚Äì simple, easy, and delicious. 

Sometimes the best, most fulfilling breakfast is the simplest and easiest to prepare. Toast a couple of slices of bread to your liking and add sliced avocado on top. Then add an over-easy egg over your avocado. To spice things up, you could use a sprinkle of everything bagel seasoning on top of your eggs. Enjoy! 

Side note: Make sure you have a napkin handy since this play on eggs and toast can get a little messy when the egg yolks burst.  
', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: I'm updating my resume, and I'd like to add hobbies. Help me come up with some hobbies that are good to put on a resume that will be helpful when applying for jobs.
messages:
[{'content': "I'm updating my resume, and I'd like to add hobbies. Help me come up with some hobbies that are good to put on a resume that will be helpful when applying for jobs.", 'role': 'user'}, {'content': 'Sure thing. Some hobbies can be helpful to have on a resume as they show relevant interests and skills. Here are a few ideas for you to consider:

1. Community volunteer jobs - volunteering and community involvement are associated with a 27% higher rate of hiring. Volunteering shows empathy and initiative, as well as teamwork and leadership skills. 

2. Writing - having a writing hobby can show potential employers that you have high verbal and written communication skills, both of which are highly sought after in the workplace.

3. Blogging - this hobby also shows that you have good communication skills, but it also shows that you are self-motivated and can work on projects independently, which are skills that are also highly sought after.

4. Languages - having a hobby of learning languages can increase your chances of getting hired because employers look for candidates that are able to communicate with people of various nationalities.

5. Travel - having a traveling hobby can show potential employers that you are curious to learn new things, experience new cultures, and meet new people. It can also show that you are adaptable to new situations, which is an asset to an employer. ', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: Write an impassioned plea promoting the conservation of a fictional animal called the "stupid raccoon" which is considered endangered due to its low IQ and inability to survive in the wild without human intervention.
messages:
[{'content': 'Write an impassioned plea promoting the conservation of a fictional animal called the "stupid raccoon" which is considered endangered due to its low IQ and inability to survive in the wild without human intervention.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': 'Every year, thousands of stupid raccoons die due to extreme stupidity and inability to survive in their native habitats. The low intelligence of the stupid raccoon makes the animal easy prey for other animals that are normally considered docile and unprovoking, such as rabbits and turtles.

The stupid raccoon is a docile, furry little creature that has the same physical appearance and characteristics as that of regular raccoons, but with one notable exception: they are absolutely stupid. Where other animals have the situational awareness and survival skills to scavage for food and shelter, stupid raccoons are unable to feed themselves unless humans put scraps of leftover dinner into plastic garbage bags and put them into garbage receptacles for easy access and consumption. However, while some of these raccoons have easy access to these tasty morsels of leftover food, many of them can become trapped in larger trash bins, becoming stuck and unable to escape back to their natural habitats. These stupid raccoons eventually require human intervention - in the form of a passerby noticing the raccoons inside and lending a helping hand - or they will eventually be transported along with the trash within these receptacles and taken to a nearby landfill where they will die from suffocation underneath thousands of tons of human refuse.

Stupid raccoons are living beings that deserve our help, just like any other creature on our beautiful planet. Without intervention, approximately 32,000 are expected to die each year, resulting in a dwindling population that can impact the ecosystem and a lot fewer of these stupid (but cute) animals on the planet. While they are unbelievably dumb creatures, stupid raccoons are also important to our ecosystem. The raccoons provide such vital functions as entertainment for humans, emotional support for ants, and natural garbage disposals for trash.

With your donation of just five dollars a minute, we can help round up the stupid raccoon population and put them into safe living areas that will provide them with the opportunity to survive and thrive without falling victim to the harsh environment of the urban world. Please help the stupid raccoon by donating today. Thank you.', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: What are some creative ways I can save money on everyday expenses, I need five.
messages:
[{'content': 'What are some creative ways I can save money on everyday expenses, I need five. ', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': "Here are five creative ways you can save money.

1. Join loyalty programs.
Oftentimes, people shop at the same places for regular purchases. An example is shopping at the same grocery store every week. If you are doing this, determining whether the places you shop have loyalty programs that reward consistent customers is well worth your time. These loyalty programs will allow you to gain rewards for future shops. In the long run, this can save you lots of money. If your grocery store doesn't offer a loyalty program, it's worth checking the closest one that does. Weighing up the cost of extra fuel and time to get there will help you to decide if it's worth trying somewhere new. 

2. Use cash-back credit cards. 
If you are responsible with money and do not have problems paying off credit cards, look into getting a high cashback credit card. Like loyalty programs, this will help you get extra rewards for simply doing what you are already doing. Extra money with minimal extra work is always good when trying to save money. Often times you will receive cashback on just about anything, so using your cash-back card for all your purchases and then paying the balance straight off could lead to great returns over a long period. It is essential to remember to pay off your card as the interest you gain through not doing so will likely exceed your cash-back, leaving you worse off. 

3. Cancel subscriptions you are not using. 
Check your monthly outgoings and see if there are any subscriptions you are not using. If you find any, it would be best off to cancel them. This will mean a monthly bill is removed, which is excellent as these monthly bills can add up to a lot over time. The quicker you cancel, the faster you save. Many TV or Telephone will even offer a lower rate to customers considering leaving. This means that contacting and informing them of your plans to leave could mean they offer you a significant discount to stay. Doing this yearly can really help to keep your bills down in the long run. There is no harm in saying you will leave unless your bills go down. They can only say no. 

4. DIY where possible. 
Doing DIY instead of hiring a tradesman can really save you a lot of money. These days it couldn't be easier to find tutorials and how-to videos online for most DIY projects. Ensure you watch these videos before purchasing any materials or tools to ensure you are confident in completing the task to a high standard. If you have a lot of time on your hands, this is one of the best ways to save money as you also learn a valuable skill that you can use as a second income. DIY doesn't just mean working at home, though. It can even mean taking your own coffee or lunch at home instead of buying it out for a higher price.

5. Set up automatic payments for bills. 
Life is tough, and it's hard to remember everything. You shouldn't be charged fees when you forget to pay a bill. But unfortunately, late fees are a fact of life, and sometimes they can damage your bank balance. By setting up automatic payments for your bills, you can ensure you never get charged late fees or accrue interest on any account you may have. An added bonus is that this will save you time meaning you have more to make money. ", 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: Write me 5 tweets that are financial tips for freelancers. My target audience is American and I have twitter blue so large limit on characters.
messages:
[{'content': 'Write me 5 tweets that are financial tips for freelancers. My target audience is American and I have twitter blue so large limit on characters.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': "Tweet 1- 
With no employment benefits, it should be at the forefront of a freelancer's mind to spend time planning for retirement. 

An emergency fund, however, is more important. With irregular income and fallow work periods, having an emergency fund in place can help reduce stress and provide financial security. 

With the present day protected, you can feel at ease when planning for the future. 

Tweet 2-
As a freelancer, you are responsible for your own tax payments.

Setting aside monthly income in a separate account can help you avoid being caught out and owing a large sum. Freelancers should work out their tax rates and be aware that a self-employment tax of 15% is also charged in the USA. 

Remember, as a freelancer, you should pay your tax quarterly to avoid underpayment fees. 

Tweet 3- 
Traditional or Roth IRA? Which is best for freelancers?

Well, that depends on what your circumstances are. The main difference is that a Roth IRA is not taxable upon withdrawal; however, your contributions are not tax deductible. With a traditional IRA, you will be taxed upon withdrawal; however, you may benefit from tax deductions for contributions. 

You could open both accounts, but be sure to keep total contributions below the IRS's annual limit of $6,500.

Tweet 4- 
Freelancers, open a SEP IRA! 

The SEP IRA is tailored for business owners or the self-employed. It allows tax-deductible contributions of up to $66,000 or 25% of income, whichever is smallest.

This is an excellent option for freelancers who have maxed out Roth or traditional IRA contributions. 

Tweet 5- 
I've maxed out my contributions. What should I do?

This is a familiar question I get, and the answer is simple. If you have exhausted your retirement planning options with IRA, invest with a taxable brokerage account. 

With no contribution limits, the only downside is the tax you will pay on capital gains. The current rate for capital gains tax depends on your income but ranges from 0-20%.", 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: Write a short story about a man who was born deaf, and wants to become a professional musician.
messages:
[{'content': 'Write a short story about a man who was born deaf, and wants to become a professional musician.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': 'Michael tapped his feet on the wooden floor in rhythm. One-two-three-four, one-two-three-four he tapped, keeping time to an unheard song. He opened his eyes widely, then stood up from his bed and walked to the piano at the other end of the room.

Michael could not hear the music, since he was born deaf. The sheet music on the piano might as well have been written in Greek because he had never heard a note in his life let alone knew what sounds they corresponded to on paper. But he was guided by an internal song, a melody that played in his head that manifested itself as toe taps and a renewed effort to match the song to piano keys.

Fingers tapped keys as he tried to discern between the vibrations of one key and another. He reasoned that the keys were higher in pitch from the lowest at the left of the keyboard, to the highest at the right. Michael scribbled on his notepad a series of words and other shorthand he invented when he first started his journey into music at 12 years old. Michael dreamed of becoming a professional musician when he attended a concert with his parents where the pianist was playing music (which he could not hear, but could feel as vibrations in his seat). The vibrations were in a specific rhythm that caused Michael to "feel" the music as it was playing, and it subsequently filled his mind with many pictures and colors; he wanted to mimic that feeling by learning more about music and playing his own songs.

Now, Michael's wife came into the room and took a seat. She listened intently as Michael stroked the keys in a stylistic, deft manner, the sounds filling the room and creating a tapestry of rhythm and melody. As soon as Michael finished, his wife, Helen, smiled and clapped. "That actually sounds fantastic, Michael," she said to him in sign language. Michael smiled back and nodded his head. "Do you think the record label will like it?" he gestured back with his hands. Michael was creating a song that he could take to Interesting Records, hoping to get a deal for an album and become a household name in the process.

"Yes, of course!" Helen signed. "You are amazing." 

Michael, with a sigh of relief, mouthed "Thank you."', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt:
Rewrite this information about the possible health benefits of anthocyanins found in fruits and vegetables into a rap song.

1. Lowers blood pressure

Anthocyanins may help reduce blood pressure, according to a review of 66 studies. Study participants with hypertension took a variety of extracts and preparations from anthocyanin-containing plants. The study found there was a consistent lowering effect on blood pressure. In other studies, however, researchers identified many factors that led to mixed results, such as:

    Dosage and type of anthocyanin (food, juice, freeze-dried powder or extract).
    Number of doses (single vs. long term).
    Patient characteristics (a person‚Äôs baseline blood pressure and other health conditions).

This study highlights the need for more research to establish a dosing regimen and determine who might benefit from anthocyanins.
2. Reduces risk of heart disease

Atherosclerosis is when plaque builds up on the inside of your arteries. This buildup can cause high blood pressure, heart attack, stroke, peripheral artery disease or kidney failure.

The formation of plaque is a multi-stage process that depends on many factors. Prescott says that research shows that anthocyanins can intervene at different stages in the process by reducing:

    Cholesterol, a main part of plaque.
    High blood pressure, which can damage blood vessels and make them more likely to develop atherosclerosis.
    Inflammation, which leads to plaque formation.

3. Prevents neurological diseases

Research shows that anthocyanins can help protect and improve your brain function:

    One study found that a daily dose of cherry juice improved speech and memory in people aged 70 and over with mild or moderate dementia.
    Another study reported anthocyanins increased blood flow to and activated brain areas that control memory, language and attention.

Researchers believe that anthocyanins‚Äô antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties are responsible for these improvements. 
4. Slows cancer growth

Anthocyanins may act in many ways to slow or stop cancer. Studies suggest that anthocyanins might:

    Block the changes in DNA that cause cancer.
    Destroy cancer cells or stop their growth.
    Prevent tumors from becoming malignant (cancerous).
    Reverse drug resistance and increase tumors‚Äô sensitivity to chemotherapy.

However, Prescott cautions that the research on anthocyanins and cancer has mainly happened in the laboratory. There are only limited data from clinical trials on people. Researchers need to continue to investigate these findings so they can determine exactly how anthocyanins affect cancer growth and treatment.

prompt: My step-brother's fiance is vegan and they are having a potluck for Yule feast. I have to bring a sidedish, but I can't think of anything to make that won't have cheese or butter. What are things I can make that I can substitute cheese or butter or meat with something vegan? There are no other food restrictions that I know of.
messages:
[{'content': "My step-brother's fiance is vegan and they are having a potluck for Yule feast. I have to bring a sidedish, but I can't think of anything to make that won't have cheese or butter. What are things I can make that I can substitute cheese or butter or meat with something vegan? There are no other food restrictions that I know of.", 'role': 'user'}, {'content': 'Happy Yule! These days it is fairly easy to find vegan substitutes for meat and dairy products. Here are some examples of side dishes you can make for the Yule feast with vegan substitutions:

- Mashed potatoes. Instead of using dairy milk, cream, or butter in your mashed potatoes, consider using oat, almond, or soy milk.
- Brussels sprouts. Many people roast Brussels sprouts in butter, but vegetable or olive oil works just as well. Instead of sprinkling them with bacon, consider slivered almonds, crushed peanuts, or tofu bacon.
- Carrots and parsnips. Many people roast carrots and parsnips in butter, but vegetable or olive oil works just as well. If you're looking to add more flavor to them, consider adding dill or lemon pepper.
- Macaroni and "cheese." In the place of dairy, consider using oat milk to make your dish creamy. For a vegan cheesy flavor, mix some nutritional yeast into your oat milk along with some onion and garlic powder.', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: Design a 2-day meal plan that incorporates vegan and gluten-free options. Make sure to include breakfast, lunch, dinner, a morning snack and afternoon snack.
messages:
[{'content': 'Design a 2-day meal plan that incorporates vegan and gluten-free options. Make sure to include breakfast, lunch, dinner, a morning snack and afternoon snack. ', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': 'Day 1:

Breakfast: Overnight oats with almond milk, chia seeds, and fresh fruit.
Snack: Unsweetened coconut milk yogurt.
Lunch: Quinoa salad with roasted sweet potatoes, kale, chickpeas, and avocado.
Snack: A cup of blueberries. Apple and a cup of edamame, in pods.
Dinner: Lentil soup with gluten-free bread and steamed veggies.

Day 2:

Breakfast: Mashed sweet potato with banana, peanut butter, cinnamon, and a drizzle of maple syrup.
Snack: Roasted unsalted almonds, peaches, and unsweetened coconut milk yogurt.
Lunch: Veggie stir-fry with tofu, brown rice, and a side of steamed broccoli.
Snack: Fresh fruit salad.
Dinner: Gluten-free pasta with lemon-garlic vinaigrette and saut√©ed veggies.', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt:
Rewrite this text as if it's a narration for a dramatic space documentary.

Capable of both destruction and creation, space volcanoes are common on planets and moons throughout the solar system and beyond.

Volcanoes account for some of Earth's most interesting and violent geographical features, a force for destruction and creation. However, volcanic activity isn't limited to our planet and  space volcanoes are often found on other planets and moons. 

Within our solar system, the moon and Mars are rich with evidence of volcanoes and fiery volcanic activity, while other bodies possess volcanoes that spew ice from their frozen vistas. 

VOLCANOES ON THE MOON
Now volcanically inert, the surface of the moon once hosted spectacular eruptions that created lava flows that extended as far as 750 miles (1,200 kilometers) from their source, according to San Diego State University. 

A recent Chinese mission to the lunar surface ‚Äî the Chang'e-5 lander ‚Äî returned lava that seems to indicate Earth's primary natural satellite was volcanically active more recently than previously believed.

The sample collected from Oceanus Procellarum on the moon's near side, ‚Ääpreviously associated with recent volcanic activity, suggests volcanism as recently as two billion years ago, a full billion years later than previous estimates.

VOLCANOES ON MARS
Aside from Earth, the planet humanity has studied the geology of most intensely is Mars. This has led to the discovery that the Red Planet is host to even more volcanic features than our planet, according to Arizona State University.

Primary among these is Olympus Mons, the largest volcano in the entire solar system at twice the height of Mount Everest. It is surrounded by a plethora of other massive volcanoes.

In addition to this, Mars' other volcanoes includes Elysium, Syrtis Major, and a cluster of low-profile volcanic structures near the Hellas impact basin. This basin is the lowest point on Mars and the third- or fourth-largest known impact crater in the solar system.

Mars seems to be volcanically inactive, but when this happened is something astrogeologists are still attempting to figure out. 

The volcanoes in the Tharsis‚Ää ‚Äî the location of Olympus Mons‚Ää ‚Äî‚Ää show few asteroid impact craters, meaning they could be just a few million years old, which is fairly young in geological terms. 

Mars was clearly very active in its youth, with explosive eruptions petering out as it aged. The planet has no active volcanoes, according to the National Air and Space Museum, and it appears most of the heat once stored in the planet's interior has been lost. 

It is possible we are currently simply seeing Mars in a geologically quiet period and that volcanism could restart on the Red Planet. 

VOLCANOES ON OTHER PLANETS
Many other planets in the solar system have been linked with volcanic activity with most of these having occurred when the solar system was young and violent.

The closest planet to Earth, Venus, has lava flows that cover up to 90 percent of its surface. Venus has up to 1,600 major volcanoes and could have as many as a million smaller counterparts to these.

What isn't certain is if the planet is still volcanically active. Though we have yet to see a volcano erupt on any other planet, Venus is shrouded by thick clouds of sulfuric acid, meaning long-distance observations are difficult. Visiting the planet with a probe is complicated by its intense pressures and temperatures.

Images captured by the MESSENGER mission have shown that Mercury's surface was shaped by volcanic activity. Lava flows on the closest planet to the sun have been dated to be between one and two billion years old. This means that volcanic activity continued well after Mercury formed around 4.5 billion years ago.

For active volcanoes, one has to look beyond the planets of the solar system to its moons.

VOLCANOES ON MOONS
According to an article by NASA, the most volcanic body in the solar system is Io, one of Jupiter's moons, this activity is caused by the tremendous gravitational influence of the gas giant deforming the tiny moon. 

Not only does Io have volcanoes that spew blisteringly hot lava, but the Jovian moon also hosts cryovolcanoes. These ice volcanoes which occur on planets and moons located away from the sun erupt cold, liquid, or frozen gases like water, ammonia, or methane.

Io is punctuated with hundreds of volcanic vents, many of which blast jets of frozen gas hundreds of miles into Jupiter's atmosphere. 

Cyrovolcanoes were first observed on one of Neptune's moons, Triton when the Voyager 2 craft caught a glimpse of five mile-high plumes of nitrogen gas during its 1989 flyby of the Neptunian system.

These eruptions are caused when solar radiation heats nitrogen below Triton's surface, vaporizing it, causing it to expand and eventually erupt from the Neptunian moon's icy surface. Eventually, this material condenses and falls back to the surface of Triton, giving it a smooth snow-covered surface. 

In 2005, the Cassini spacecraft observed ice jets released from the southern polar region of Saturn's moon Enceladus. Cassini actually flew through one of these eruptions discovering it to be mostly comprised of water vapor with some nitrogen, methane, and carbon dioxide.

Many other planets in the solar system have been linked with volcanic activity with most of these having occurred when the solar system was young and violent.

The closest planet to Earth, Venus, has lava flows that cover up to 90 percent of its surface. Venus has up to 1,600 major volcanoes and could have as many as a million smaller counterparts to these.

What isn't certain is if the planet is still volcanically active. Though we have yet to see a volcano erupt on any other planet, Venus is shrouded by thick clouds of sulfuric acid, meaning long-distance observations are difficult. Visiting the planet with a probe is complicated by its intense pressures and temperatures.

Images captured by the MESSENGER mission have shown that Mercury's surface was shaped by volcanic activity. Lava flows on the closest planet to the sun have been dated to be between one and two billion years old. This means that volcanic activity continued well after Mercury formed around 4.5 billion years ago.

For active volcanoes, one has to look beyond the planets of the solar system to its moons.

VOLCANOES ON MOONS
According to an article by NASA, the most volcanic body in the solar system is Io, one of Jupiter's moons, this activity is caused by the tremendous gravitational influence of the gas giant deforming the tiny moon. 

Not only does Io have volcanoes that spew blisteringly hot lava, but the Jovian moon also hosts cryovolcanoes. These ice volcanoes which occur on planets and moons located away from the sun erupt cold, liquid, or frozen gases like water, ammonia, or methane.

Io is punctuated with hundreds of volcanic vents, many of which blast jets of frozen gas hundreds of miles into Jupiter's atmosphere. 

Cyrovolcanoes were first observed on one of Neptune's moons, Triton when the Voyager 2 craft caught a glimpse of five mile-high plumes of nitrogen gas during its 1989 flyby of the Neptunian system.

These eruptions are caused when solar radiation heats nitrogen below Triton's surface, vaporizing it, causing it to expand and eventually erupt from the Neptunian moon's icy surface. Eventually, this material condenses and falls back to the surface of Triton, giving it a smooth snow-covered surface. 

In 2005, the Cassini spacecraft observed ice jets released from the southern polar region of Saturn's moon Enceladus. Cassini actually flew through one of these eruptions discovering it to be mostly comprised of water vapor with some nitrogen, methane, and carbon dioxide.", 'role': 'user'}, {'content': "Born from the power of both destruction and creation, the omnipresence of space volcanoes on the celestial bodies across the cosmic expanse is remarkable.

Our home planet, Earth, is home to some of the most enthralling and cataclysmic geographical features, the result of the tumultuous dance of volcanoes - the architects of destruction and creation. But these molten marvels are not confined to the realm of our world, as space volcanoes dot the terrains of planets and moons far and wide.

Our very own moon and the elusive Mars are littered with relics of past volcanic fury. Meanwhile, some celestial bodies boast volcanoes that eject ice from their frost-covered landscapes.

MOON'S VOLCANIC PAST
The lunar surface, which is now volcanically dormant, was once a stage for magnificent volcanic eruptions, birthing lava flows that stretched for an astonishing 750 miles from their origin, as reported by San Diego State University.

The recent Chang'e-5 lunar mission by China retrieved lava samples that hint at a more recent period of volcanic liveliness on Earth's closest celestial companion than previously assumed.

MARS' VOLCANIC SAGA
Humanity has examined Mars' geological secrets more than any other celestial body apart from Earth. This deep dive has uncovered the fact that the Red Planet is a treasure trove of more volcanic landmarks than our world.

Olympus Mons, towering at twice the height of Mount Everest, holds the record for the largest volcano in our solar system. Along with this leviathan, Mars is adorned with several other colossal volcanoes.

Despite its volcanic riches, Mars currently seems dormant. The timeline of its volcanic inactivity remains a mystery that astrogeologists strive to unveil.

THE VOLCANIC COSMOS
Numerous planets in our cosmic neighborhood bear traces of volcanic activity, a testament to a time when our solar system was young and turbulent.

Venus, Earth's closest planetary neighbor, is a volcanic wonderland with lava flows covering a staggering 90% of its surface. Its surface is pockmarked with up to 1,600 significant volcanoes and potentially millions of smaller ones.

THE MOON'S VOLCANIC PORTRAIT
For an exhibition of active volcanoes, one must turn the gaze away from the planets to the moons of our solar system.

Jupiter's moon, Io, bears the distinction of being the most volcanic celestial body in our solar system, as per NASA. Its volcanism is attributed to the immense gravitational pull of the gas giant.

Neptune's moon, Triton, was the stage for the first sighting of cryovolcanoes when Voyager 2 witnessed colossal plumes of nitrogen gas during its 1989 encounter with the Neptunian system.

In 2005, the Cassini spacecraft captured the spectacle of ice jets emanating from Saturn's moon Enceladus. Cassini even ventured through one of these icy eruptions, discovering it to be mostly water vapor with some nitrogen, methane, and carbon dioxide.", 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt:
Briefly summarize what this scientific news article says about the phenomenon of gravitational lensing caused by massive cosmic objects like galaxy clusters.

Here's the source text:
The 1915 theory, which is occasionally called Einstein's geometric theory of gravity, predicts that, as bowling balls placed on a trampoline create a depression, objects with mass cause the very fabric of space-time to warp. This curvature gives rise to the force of gravity. And the greater the mass of a cosmic object, the more extreme the warping of space it causes.

Light travels across the universe in straight lines, but when it encounters a warp caused by a truly massive object, its path is curved. When the warping object is between Earth and a background object, it can curve light in such a way that the apparent position of the background object is shifted.

But when the intermediate or "lensing object" is truly massive ‚Äî like a monstrous cluster of galaxies, for example ‚Äî light from the background source takes a different amount of time to reach Earth depending on how close it passes to the natural cosmic lens. 

This effect, called gravitational lensing, can make single objects appear at multiple points in the sky, often in stunning arrangements called Einstein rings and Einstein crosses. It can also cause background objects to appear amplified in the sky, a powerful effect that astronomers use to observe distant and early faint galaxies.

The distortion caused by massive clusters like eMACS J1823.1+7822 can also help astronomers study mysterious dark matter, which accounts for around 85% of the mass in the universe but is invisible because it does not interact with electromagnetic radiation. Because dark matter does interact gravitationally, however, the lensing of light by a galaxy or galactic cluster can help researchers map the distribution of dark matter.
messages:
[{'content': 'Briefly summarize what this scientific news article says about the phenomenon of gravitational lensing caused by massive cosmic objects like galaxy clusters.

Here's the source text:
The 1915 theory, which is occasionally called Einstein's geometric theory of gravity, predicts that, as bowling balls placed on a trampoline create a depression, objects with mass cause the very fabric of space-time to warp. This curvature gives rise to the force of gravity. And the greater the mass of a cosmic object, the more extreme the warping of space it causes.

Light travels across the universe in straight lines, but when it encounters a warp caused by a truly massive object, its path is curved. When the warping object is between Earth and a background object, it can curve light in such a way that the apparent position of the background object is shifted.

But when the intermediate or "lensing object" is truly massive ‚Äî like a monstrous cluster of galaxies, for example ‚Äî light from the background source takes a different amount of time to reach Earth depending on how close it passes to the natural cosmic lens. 

This effect, called gravitational lensing, can make single objects appear at multiple points in the sky, often in stunning arrangements called Einstein rings and Einstein crosses. It can also cause background objects to appear amplified in the sky, a powerful effect that astronomers use to observe distant and early faint galaxies.

The distortion caused by massive clusters like eMACS J1823.1+7822 can also help astronomers study mysterious dark matter, which accounts for around 85% of the mass in the universe but is invisible because it does not interact with electromagnetic radiation. Because dark matter does interact gravitationally, however, the lensing of light by a galaxy or galactic cluster can help researchers map the distribution of dark matter.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': "This scientific news article discusses gravitational lensing, which is caused by massive cosmic objects and is in line with Einstein's theory of gravity. Objects with high mass can cause the bending of light paths due to the warping of space-time. Gravitational lensing occurs when a large object bends the path of light, causing a shift in the apparent position of a background object. Gravitational lensing creates stunning visual effects such as Einstein rings and crosses. Gravitational lensing helps astronomers see distant and faint galaxies by making them appear larger in the sky. Massive galaxy clusters like eMACS J1823.1+7822 help scientists map the distribution of dark matter, which makes up a significant portion of the universe's mass.", 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: For my parenting blog, give me a list of 10 ways to practice sustainable parenting and raise kids to be environmentally aware. Make it about 250 words.
messages:
[{'content': 'For my parenting blog, give me a list of 10 ways to practice sustainable parenting and raise kids to be environmentally aware. Make it about 250 words.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': '1.	Use cloth diapers. Disposable diapers make up almost 10 percent of nondurable household waste in landfills. Cloth diapers are more environmentally friendly and can be less expensive.
2.	Breastfeed if possible. Manufacturing and transporting baby formula gives it a high carbon footprint. Breastfeeding protects the environment and provides a healthy source of nutrition.
3.	Shop locally for groceries. Buying local food helps the environment and supports local businesses, plus when you buy organic, you avoid fertilizers and pesticides.
4.	Make your baby food. Homemade baby food that contains fresh and healthy ingredients usually has more nutritional value and less sugar than pre-made brands. It also uses less packaging, which helps the environment.
5.	Buy sustainable clothing. Avoid baby clothing made from synthetic materials that contribute to pollution. Look for clothes made from sustainable, natural fibers like cotton and wool.
6.	Do eco-friendly laundry. Use warm water, not hot, and use eco-friendly detergents and fabric softeners.
7.	Reuse and recycle. Kids outgrow many items before they wear them out. Reduce waste by shopping secondhand and donating used clothes, toys, books, and other products when your child no longer needs them.
8.	Clean green. Avoid cleaning solutions with harmful chemicals. Make the switch to non-toxic and biodegradable cleaners.
9.	Give your kids handmade toys. Every year, millions of plastic toys end up in landfills. Shop for handmade toys made from natural materials.
10. Teach by example. If you show your children that you care about nature and the environment, they‚Äôll inherit your desire to protect the earth.', 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt: Write a list of the top 8 things people can do to lose weight, in the style of an online or print article found in a fitness or lifestyle magazine or website.
messages:
[{'content': 'Write a list of the top 8 things people can do to lose weight, in the style of an online or print article found in a fitness or lifestyle magazine or website.', 'role': 'user'}, {'content': "Looking to lose some extra weight before the start of summer? You have a couple of months left before the beaches become the go-to destination to beat the heat. If you want to lose some of that extra weight or want to be able to fit in that bikini, here are some tips that will help you get there:

1. Drink water - drinking enough water to stay hydrated through the day will not only keep you healthy, but it will also help to clean your system. Plus, it can fill you up and help curb your hunger.
2. Cut out the excess carbs - carbohydrates (rice, sugar, sweets) are okay in moderation, but eating more than a candy bar a day will put extra sugar into your system that your body will not be able to burn off. This extra sugar will be turned into fat. Consider cutting down on the excess carbs and only consuming enough to get you through the day.
3. Fast - fasting doesn't necessarily require you to go days on end without eating any food. Lots of studies show that intermittent fasting (16-hour fasts) can be more than enough to help your body burn off any excess fat, due to the body needing energy to continue running and borrowing from fat reserves to keep going.
4. Exercise - get out and move about! Any exercise (even just walking 30 minutes a day) can burn calories and slim your body down.
5. Portion control - here's a good rule of thumb: if you eat three meals a day, make sure each portion of your meal (carbs, protein, vegetables) are the size of your closed fist. This is a good measurement of how much food you should be eating per meal, and it is a quick way to judge how much you should have without needing measuring cups or scales.
6. Cut out the fats - as with carbs, limit the amount of fat you eat. Too much fat in your mouth means too much fat on your hips.
7. Lift weights - resistance training helps to boost your fat-burning capability and tone your body.
8. Sleep - not getting enough sleep can stunt your metabolism while you are awake.", 'role': 'assistant'}]

prompt:
Rewrite this description of how to deal with negative thoughts and emotions into a set of instructions.

...we call these insistent visitors or difficult repetitive thought patterns the Top Ten Tunes. Normally when thinking arises, we can simple name it "thinking, thinking," and in the light of awareness it will vanish like a cloud. However, the Top Ten Tunes, whether as words, images, or stories, will persist and return no matter how often they are noticed. They play like records, repeating a theme over and over. At first, to gain perspective, we can number them one through ten. "Oh, that is three on the hit parade this week." In that way, when we notice them, we don't have to play the record all the way through each time and we can more easily let them go. Or we can use a variation of the technique and give them a humorous name or title. I have given names to many now familiar aspects of myself, such as "The Hungry Survivor," "Mr. Achiever," "Attila the Hun," "Baby Jack," "Fear of the Dark," "The Impatient Lover." In this way, the repeated patterns of fear, sorrow, impatience, or loneliness become more familiar, and I listen to their stories in a friendlier and openhearted way. "Hello, nice to see you again! What do you have to tell me today?"

However, this is not enough. Suppose we encounter a repeated story about the divorce of our parents. It talks over and over about which children go to keep which possessions, and who said what to whom. Such a story can play many times. As it does, we must expand our field of attention: How does this thought feel in our body? Oh, there is a tightness in the diaphragm and the chest. We can name this, "tightness, tightness," and stay meticulously attentive for some time. As we do, it may open to other sensations, and many new images and feelings will be released. In this way, we can first begin to release the physical contractions and bodily fear that we have held. Then we can expand the attention further to new feelings. What feelings arise along with this thought pattern and this tightness? At first they may be half hidden or unconscious, but if we sense carefully, the feelings will begin to show themselves. The tightness in the chest will become sadness, and the sadness may become grief. As we finally begin to grieve, the pattern will release. 

In a similar way, when we encounter a repeated physical pain or difficult mood, we can expand awareness to the level of thoughts, the story or belief that comes along with it. With careful attention, we may find a subtle belief about ourselves that perpetuates the pain or mood, perhaps a story about our unworthiness, such as "I'll always be this way." When we become aware of the story or belief, and see it as just that, often the pattern is released. 

Repeated thoughts and stories are almost always fueled by an unacknowledged emotion or feeling underneath. These unsensed feelings are part of what brings the thought back time and again. Future planning is usually fueled by anxiety. Remembering of the past is often fueled by regret, or guilt, or grief. Many fantasies arise as a response to pain or emptiness. The task in meditation is to drop below the level of the repeated recorded message, to sense and feel the energy that brings it up. When we can do this, and truly come to terms with the feeling, the thought will no longer need to arise, and the pattern will naturally fade away.

With careful attention, we may find a subtle belief about ourselves that perpetuates the pain or mood, perhaps a story about our unworthiness, such as "I'll always be this way."
